revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Krisztina 'Z' Holly| image = KrisztinaZHolly.jpg | caption = Krisztina 'Z' Holly at [[Foo Camp]] 2013 in Sebastopol, CA, on August 3, 2013 | occupation = Innovator and Entrepreneur | salary = | networth = | spouse = | children = | website = | footnotes = }} '''Krisztina Holly''', known by her colleagues as 'Z'<ref name=reinventors>{{cite web |url=http://reinventors.net/content/krisztina-z-holly/ |title=Krisztina ‘Z’ Holly |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |year=2012 |website=Reinventors |publisher=Reinventors Network|accessdate=9 August 2013}}</ref> is a [[Hungarian American]] innovator, entrepreneur, and adventurer. She is the host of The Art of Manufacturing podcast<ref name=artofmfg>{{cite web |url=https://artofmfg.com |website=artofmfg.com |title=The Art of Manufacturing podcast}}</ref> and the Founder and Chief Instigator of MAKE IT IN LA,<ref name=bio>{{cite web |url=https://krisztinaholly.com |website=makeitinla.org |title=Krisztina ‘Z’ Holly bio}}</ref> which was launched from her term as Entrepreneur-in-Residence for LA Mayor Garcetti.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.socaltech.com/entrepreneurship_in_the_la_mayor_s_office_with_eir_krisztina_holly/s-0055304.html |title=Entrepreneurship In The LA Mayor's Office, With EIR Krisztina Holly |author=Benjamin F. Kuo |year=2014 |website=SoCalTech |accessdate=27 July 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lamayor.org/mayor_garcetti_launches_entrepreneur_in_residence_program |title=Mayor Garcetti Launches Entrepreneur in Residence Program |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |year=2014 |website=lamayor.org |accessdate=27 July 2014}}</ref> She is best known as the creator of the first [[TEDx]],<ref name=ted>{{cite web|title=The Story of the First TEDx Q&A with Krisztina 'Z' Holly|work=TED|url=http://blog.ted.com/2012/04/17/the-story-of-the-first-tedx-qa-with-krisztina-z-holly/|accessdate=3 August 2013}}</ref> the founding executive director of the Deshpande Center for Technological Innovation at the [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]] and the Vice Provost for Innovation and founding executive director of the Stevens Center for Innovation at the [[University of Southern California]].<ref name=entrepreneur>{{cite web|title=Radicals & Visionaries: Invention vs. Innovation|url=http://www.entrepreneur.com/article/225789|accessdate=3 August 2013}}</ref> She was founder or key team member of various technology startups including Stylus Innovation, Direct Hit Technologies, and Jeeves Solutions and was a prominent mountain bike advocate in New England for a decade.<ref name=linkedin>{{cite web |url=http://www.linkedin.com/in/krisztinaholly |title=Krisztina Holly's LinkedIn profile |website=LinkedIn |publisher=LinkedIn}}</ref> She is a founding donor and board member of the [[River LA]],<ref name=riverlaboard>{{cite web |url=http://www.riverla.org/board |website=riverla.org |title=River LA governing board}}</ref><ref name=riverladonor>{{cite web |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171209100224/http://www.riverla.org/our_founding_circle |website=riverla.org |title=River LA founding donors}}</ref> serves on the board of [[TTI/Vanguard]],<ref name=ttivanguard>{{cite web |url=http://www.ttivanguard.com/board/ |website=ttivanguard.com |title=TTI/Vanguard board of advisors}}</ref> and has been an advisor to nearly two dozen other companies and organizations, including the Obama Administration as an inaugural member of the National Advisory Council on Innovation and Entrepreneurship,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.commerce.gov/news/press-releases/2010/07/13/locke-announces-national-advisory-council-innovation-and-entrepreneur |title=Locke Announces National Advisory Council on Innovation and Entrepreneurship Members |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=July 13, 2010 |website=Commerce.gov |publisher=United States Department of Commerce |accessdate=9 August 2013}}</ref> and a global agenda council member of the [[World Economic Forum]] advising in the areas of entrepreneurship<ref name=wefentrepreneurship>{{cite web |url=http://www3.weforum.org/docs/GAC/2013/WEF_GAC_FosteringEntrepreneurship_MidtermReport.pdf |title=WEF Global Agenda Council on Fostering Entrepreneurship midterm report |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= |website=The World Economic Forum |publisher=The World Economic Forum |accessdate=9 August 2013}}</ref><ref name=fivemyths>{{cite web |url=https://www.weforum.org/agenda/2013/11/the-five-myths-that-are-hurting-entrepreneurship/ |website=weforum.org |title=World Eceonomic Forum: Five Myths that are Hurting Entrepreneurship}}</ref> and manufacturing.<ref name=wefmanufacturing>{{cite web |url=https://www.weforum.org/communities/global-agenda-council-on-the-future-of-manufacturing/ |title=WEF Global Agenda Council on the Future of Manufacturing |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= |website=The World Economic Forum |publisher=The World Economic Forum |accessdate=9 August 2013}}</ref> She is married and resides in Los Angeles.<ref name=linkedin />
==Early life== Holly was born to Hungarian parents and has written about being greatly influenced by their stories of escaping their home country in 1956 and being refugees in America.<ref name=entrepreneur /> From a young age she thought she would be an entrepreneur.<ref name=prism >{{cite web |url=http://www.prism-magazine.org/mar12/upclose.cfm |title=The ‘Z’ Factor |author=Alison Buki |date=March 2012 |website=PRISM |publisher=American Society for Engineering Education |accessdate=9 August 2013}}</ref> She attended [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]] and received bachelor's and master's degrees in mechanical engineering.<ref name=bio /> She, [[Mike Cassidy (entrepreneur)|Michael Cassidy]] and John Barrus won the [[MIT $100K Entrepreneurship Competition|MIT business plan competition]] in 1991 with Stylus Innovation, which was acquired by Artisoft in 1996 for $12.8M.<ref>{{cite web|title=USC Stevens Institute Names MIT’s Krisztina Holly Executive Director|work=USC|url=http://pressroom.usc.edu/usc-stevens-institute-names-mits-krisztina-holly-executive-director/|accessdate=3 August 2013}}</ref>
==Career==
Holly created TEDxUSC, the first ever TEDx event in 2009,<ref name=ted /> which so far inspired over 15,000 similar events globally.<ref name=tedxprogram>{{cite web |url=http://tedx.com |website=ted.com |title=TEDx program page}}</ref> In her role as curator and host for TEDxUSC over four years, she discovered and coached more than 60 presenters whose videos have garnered 12 million views online.<ref name=bio /> From 2006-2012 she was the vice provost for innovation at USC and founding executive director the USC Stevens Center for Innovation. From 2002-2006 she was the founding executive director of the MIT Deshpande Center. While at MIT and USC, she helped expand the innovation ecosystems in Boston and LA and the centers helped spin out 39 startups based on university research.<ref>{{cite web|title=Leadership Changes at USC Stevens Center for Innovation|work= USC Stevens Center for Innovation|url=http://stevens.usc.edu/read_article.php?news_id=772|accessdate=3 August 2013}}</ref>
Early on Holly was co-founder of computer telephony pioneer, Stylus Innovation (acquired by Artisoft)<ref>{{cite web|title=Inventor of the Week Archive|work=Lemelson-MIT|url=http://web.mit.edu/invent/iow/holly.html|accessdate=3 August 2013}}</ref> and subsequently joined other tech and media startups including Direct Hit Technologies (acquired by Ask Jeeves) and Jeeves Solutions.<ref>{{cite web|title= Krisztina 'Z' Holly|work= USC Stevens Center for Innovation|url=http://stevens.usc.edu/about_usc_stevens_team_krisztina_holly.php|accessdate=3 August 2013}}</ref> Between startups Holly spent nearly three years in documentary production.<ref name=prism />
Holly started her career as an undergraduate researcher at the [[MIT Media Lab]], working on the team that created the world's first full-color computer generated reflection hologram.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://web.mit.edu/invent/iow/holly.html |title=Visual Voice(TM) telephony software |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=October 2002 |website=MIT Invention Dimension |publisher=Massachusetts Institute of Technology, MIT School of Engineering |accessdate=9 August 2013}}</ref> Later, she developed a robotic weld-seam-tracking program for the space shuttle main engine and built a head-eye robot for the MIT AI Lab.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://inventors.about.com/library/inventors/blholly.htm |title=Krisztina Holly |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= |website=About.com |publisher=About.com |accessdate=9 August 2013}}</ref>
Holly was named Champion of Free Enterprise by Forbes in 2009.<ref>{{cite web|title=Paint The Ivory Tower Green|work=Forbes|url=https://www.forbes.com/forbes/2010/1122/champions-free-enterprise-krisztina-holly-ivory-tower.html|accessdate=3 August 2013}}</ref> She has been a contributor to Forbes,<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.forbes.com/2010/06/29/venture-capital-incubators-technology-breakthroughs-universities.html |title=Why Funding University Innovation Matters |author=Krisztina "Z" Holly |date=2010-06-29 |website=Forbes.com |publisher=Forbes |accessdate=9 August 2013}}</ref> The Economist,<ref>{{cite web|title=How would you describe your dream job? Discover the Millennials outlook |publisher=The Economist |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=htJi2aFAZvE&list=PLtiWyl13n05NLHEG5vy_L_nj1LKYZJ3RL|accessdate=28 July 2014}}</ref> Businessweek,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.businessweek.com/innovate/content/may2009/id20090520_115971.htm |title=CERN's Collaborative Management Model |author=Krisztina Holly |date=May 20, 2009 |website=Businessweek |publisher= |accessdate=9 August 2013}}</ref> Huffington Post,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/krisztina-holly/ |title=Krisztina Holly |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= |website=The Huffington Post |publisher=The Huffington Post |accessdate=9 August 2013}}</ref> CNN.com,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2010/OPINION/01/29/holly.innovation.universities/index.html |title=For jobs, look to university spin-offs |author=Krisztina "Z" Holly |date=January 30, 2010 |website=CNN.com |publisher= |accessdate=9 August 2013}}</ref> NASA ASK,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://appel.nasa.gov/2009/06/01/a-model-for-collaboration/ |title=A Model for Collaboration |author=Krisztina Holly |date=June 1, 2009 |publisher=NASA |accessdate=28 July 2014}}</ref> Strategy+Business,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.strategy-business.com/article/00148d?gko=988ce |title=Best Business Books 2012: Innovation - Context is King |author=Krisztina "Z" Holly |date=November 27, 2012 |website=Strategy+Business |publisher= |accessdate=9 August 2013}}</ref> World Economic Forum,<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.weforum.org/agenda/2012/11/the-democratization-of-innovation/ |title=The Democratization of Innovation |author=Krisztina "Z" Holly |date=November 15, 2012 |website=World Economic Forum |publisher= |accessdate=11 August 2016}}</ref> Science Progress,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://scienceprogress.org/2010/06/the-full-potential-of-university-research/ |title=The Full Potential of University Research |author=Krisztina "Z" Holly |date=June 8, 2010 |website=Science Progress |publisher= |accessdate=9 August 2013}}</ref> Innovation Management,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.innovationmanagement.se/2011/02/18/developing-innovation-ecosystems-around-universities/ |title=Developing Innovation Ecosystems Around Universities |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= |website=Innovation Management.se |publisher= |accessdate=9 August 2013}}</ref> and Mountain Bike Magazine.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www3.telus.net/djlassmann/trails/onetrack/bars.html |title=Waterbars |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= |website=The Singletrack Classroom |publisher= |accessdate=9 August 2013}}</ref> She has also served as a board member or advisor for numerous organizations and is a member of YPO.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ted.com/profiles/60693 |title=TED Community » Krisztina 'Z' Holly |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= |website=TED.com |publisher= |accessdate=9 August 2013}}</ref> In 2013, Krisztina served as a mentor for Unreasonable at Sea, a technology business accelerator for social entrepreneurs seeking to scale their ventures in international markets, founded by Unreasonable Group, [[Semester at Sea]], and [[Stanford]]’s [[Hasso Plattner Institute of Design]].<ref>{{Cite news| url = http://www.semesteratsea.org/discover-sas/signature-programs/past-programs/unreasonable-at-sea/ |title= An Unreasonable Opportunity in Spring 2013|publisher=[[Semester at Sea]] |accessdate = April 25, 2015}}</ref>
==Hobbies==
Holly is a licensed skydiver and SCUBA instructor,<ref>{{cite web |url=https://vimeo.com/60168141 |title=Unreasonable at Sea Interview: Krisztina "Z" Holly on the Future of Universities|author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= |website=Vimeo |publisher=Unreasonable Media |accessdate=9 August 2013}}</ref> and an avid backcountry/telemark skier, adventure traveler, mountain biker, shark diver,<ref>{{cite web|title=Krisztina "Z" Holly|work=Unreasonable at Sea|url=http://unreasonableatsea.com/portfolio/krisztina-z-holly/|accessdate=3 August 2013}}</ref> and authentic food aficionado.<ref>{{cite web|title= Krisztina 'Z' Holly|work=LinkedIn|url=http://www.linkedin.com/in/krisztinaholly|accessdate=3 August 2013}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
==External links== * [http://krisztinaholly.com/ Official bio] * [http://www.linkedin.com/in/krisztinaholly LinkedIn profile] * [http://artofmfg.com The Art of Manufacturing podcast page]
{{authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Holly, Krisztina}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:MIT Media Lab people]] [[Category:Technology company founders]] [[Category:American people of Hungarian descent]] [[Category:Women company founders]] [[Category:Hungarian mechanical engineers]] [[Category:American women engineers]] [[Category:Hungarian company founders]] [[Category:American company founders]] [[Category:American mechanical engineers]] [[Category:Women in engineering]] [[Category:Massachusetts Institute of Technology alumni]] [[Category:21st-century women engineers]]

revision.comment: Reverted edits by [[Special:Contributions/122.107.167.102|122.107.167.102]] ([[User talk:122.107.167.102|talk]]) ([[WP:HG|HG]]) (3.4.3)
revision.text:
[[Image:Geomembrana AGS.jpg|thumbnail|300px|right|A landfill in México showing geomembrane in one of the slopes.]] [[Image:Landfill_Hawaii.jpg|thumbnail|300px|right|A landfill cell showing a rubberized liner in place on the left.]]
A '''landfill liner''', or '''composite liner''', is intended to be a low permeable barrier, which is laid down under engineered [[landfill]] sites. Until it deteriorates, the liner retards migration of [[leachate]], and its toxic constituents, into underlying [[aquifer]]s or nearby rivers, causing spoliation of the local water.
Modern landfills generally require a layer of compacted [[clay]] with a minimum required thickness and a maximum allowable [[hydraulic conductivity]], overlaid by a [[high-density polyethylene]] [[geomembrane]].
The [[United States Environmental Protection Agency]] has stated that the barriers "will ultimately fail," while the site remains a threat for "thousands of years," suggesting that modern landfill designs delay but do not prevent ground and surface water pollution.<ref>[http://www.gfredlee.com/Landfills/NRC_EngrBarriers.pdf gfredlee.com] - National Research Council of the National Academies (2007): ''Assessment of the Performance of Engineered Waste Containment Barriers''. Committee to Assess the Performance of Engineered Barriers. Washington DC.</ref>
Chipped or [[waste tires]] are used to support and insulate the liner.<ref>Benson, C. H., Olson, M. A. & Bergstrom, W. R. (1996) [http://pubsindex.trb.org/document/view/default.asp?lbid=468017 Temperatures of Insulated Landfill Liner], p24-31</ref>
==Types== There are certain levels of harmfulness in which the different types of trash have; therefore, there are different types of liner systems which are required for these different types of disposal sites. The first type is single liner-systems. These systems usually are put within landfills which mostly hold construction rubble. These landfills are not meant to hold the disposal of harmful liquid wastes such as paint, tar, or any other type of liquid garbage that can easily seep through a single liner system. The second type is [[double-liner]] systems. These systems are usually found in municipal solid waste landfills as well all hazardous waste landfills. The first part is constructed to collect the leachate while the second layer is engineered to be a leak-detection system to ensure that no contaminates leak into the ground and contaminate everything.<ref>Hughes, Kerry L. "Ohio State University Fact Sheet." Landfill Types and Liner Systems, CDFS-138-05 (2005). Retrieved from the website: http://ohioline.osu.edu/cd-fact/0138.html</ref>
==Components== Composite liners are required to be used in municipal solid waste systems for [[landfills]] and use a double liner system which is composed of a [[leachate]] system which is a liquid that collects solids from the substance this is passed through it. The leachate system is surrounded in a by a type of solid drainage layer such as gravel which is enclosed by a geomembrane and compressed clay, also known as a [[geosynthetic clay liner]]. This geosynthetic clay liner is usually made of sodium bentonite which is compacted in between two thick pieces of geotextile. The next material surrounding the composite liner would be a leak detection system composed of another material like gravel with an additional geomembrane or complex liner.<ref>Composite liners improve landfill performance. (1997). Civil Engineering (08857024), 67(12), 18. </ref> The geomembranes within the composite liner consist of a high-density polyethylene which provide an effective minimization for flow and deliver and helpful barrier which is used on inorganic contaminants.<ref>Rowe, R., & Rimal, S. S. (2008). Depletion of Antioxidants from an HDPE Geomembrane in a Composite Liner. Journal of Geotechnical & Geoenvironmental Engineering, 134(1), 68-78. doi:10.1061/(ASCE)1090-0241(2008)134:1(68)</ref> It can be used as a substitute for sand or gravel and also has a very high transmissivity and low storage. The lower surface helps provide an effective leak test once correctly installed. It is also a low permeable vapor and liquid barrier. The geosynthetic clay liners are manufactured by factories and the purpose for it being made of sodium [[bentonite]] is that they regulate the movement of liquids in gases within the waste.<ref>Scalia, J., & Benson, C. H. (2011). Hydraulic Conductivity of Geosynthetic Clay Liners Exhumed from Landfill Final Covers with Composite Barriers. Journal of Geotechnical & Geoenvironmental Engineering, 137(1), 1-13. doi:10.1061/(ASCE)GT.1943-5606.0000407 </ref> The geocomposites which are a combination of the geomembranes and geosynthetic liner material also include a layer of bentonite between the middle of the layers of geotextile; however, airspace is allowed to be implemented. It is then topped off with a final cover.
==How it works== The main role a composite liner has for a municipal solid waste system for landfills is that is reduces the amount of leakage through small seep holes that sometimes form in the geomembrane part of the composite liner. The protection layer part serves as a preventer from these holes from forming inside the geomembrane which would allow the waste to leak through the entire liner(awkward sentence consider rewording). It also takes away the pressure and stress which can cause cracking and holes from forming in the membrane as well.<ref>Dickinson, S. S., & Brachman, R. I. (2008). Assessment of alternative protection layers for a [[geomembrane]] – geosynthetic clay liner (GM–GCL) composite liner. Canadian Geotechnical Journal, 45(11), 1594-1610.</ref> An effective liner in a landfill system should be able to control water in terms of movement and protection on the environment. It should be able to regulate the flow away from the waste area and withhold the waste contents as it enters the actual landfill. Due to the effectiveness on how landfills are placed on top of slopes in order for the water to stream downhill and in an emergency, into the actual landfill. Water moves through the landfill and downward through the composite liner. The main purpose for all of this is so that the movement is lateral which lessens the probability for slope catastrophe and the waste leaking down and freely contaminating whatever is in its path. The final cover functions as a way to keep the water out of the contaminate and to control the runoff from entering the system. This helps prevent plants and animals from being harmed by the waste contaminated water,leachate. Using gravity and pumps the leachate is able to be pushed to a [[sump]] where it is removed by a pump. When developing composite liners it is extremely important to take in risk factors such as earthquakes and other slope failure problems that could occur.<ref>O'Leary, P., & Walsh, P. (2002). Landfill cover and liner systems for water quality protection. Waste Age, 33(4), 124-129. Retrieved from http://search.proquest.com/docview/219247584</ref> '''Composite liner'''s are used in [[municipal solid waste]] (MSW) [[landfill]]s to reduce [[water pollution]]. A composite liner is made of a [[geomembrane]] along with a [[geosynthetic clay liner]]. Composite-liner systems are better at reducing [[leachate]] migration into the [[subsoil]] than either a clay liner or a single geomembrane layer.<ref name="TITLE 40 part 258">{{cite web |url=http://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/CFR-2012-title40-vol26/xml/CFR-2012-title40-vol26-part258.xml |title=PART 258 - CRITERIA FOR MUNICIPAL SOLID WASTE LANDFILLS |publisher=gpo.gov }}</ref>
== Mechanical properties == The primary forms of mechanical degradation associated with geomembranes result from insufficient tensile strength, tear resistance, impact resistance, puncture resistance, and susceptibility to environmental stress cracking (ESC). The ideal method of assessing the amount of liner degradation would be by examining field samples over their service life. Due to the lengths of time required for field sampling tests, various laboratory-accelerated ageing tests have been developed to measure the important mechanical properties.<ref>Rowe, R. Kerry, S Rimal, and S Rimal. 2008. Aging of HDPE Geomembrane in Three Composite Landfill Liner Configurations. Journal of Geotechnical & Geoenvironmental Engineering. 134, no. 7: 906-916.</ref>
=== Tensile strength === Tensile strength represents the ability for a geomembrane to resist tensile stress. Geomembranes are most commonly tested for tensile strength using one of three methods; the uniaxial tensile test described in ASTM D639-94, the wide-strip tensile test described in ASTM D4885-88, and the multiaxial tension test described in ASTM D5617-94. The difference in these three methods lies in the boundaries imposed into the test specimens. Uniaxial tests do not provide lateral restraint during testing and thus tests the sample under uniaxial stress conditions. During the wide-strip test the sample is restrained laterally while the middle portion is unrestrained. The multiaxial tensile test provides a plane stress boundary condition at the edges of the sample.<ref>Wesseloo, J, AT Visser, and E Rust. 2004. A Mathematical Model for the Strain-rate Dependent Stress-strain Response of HDPE Geomembranes. Geotextiles and Geomembranes. 22, no. 4: 273-295.</ref> A typical range of tensile strengths in the machine direction are from 225 to 245 lb/in for 60-mil HDPE to 280 to 325 lb/in for 80-mil HDPE.<ref name="sharma">Sharma, Hari and Reddy, Krishna. 2004. Geoenvironmental Engineering: Site Remediation, Waste Containment, and Emerging Waste Management Technologies. John Wiley & Sons, Inc., Hoboken, New Jersey.</ref>
=== Tear resistance === Tear resistance of a geomembrane becomes important when it is exposed to high winds or handling stress during installation. There are various ASTM methods for measuring tear resistance of geomembranes, with most common reports using ASTM D1004. Typical tear resistances show a value of 40 to 45 lb for 60-mil HDPE and 50 to 60 lb for 80-mil HDPE.<ref name="sharma"/>
=== Impact resistance === Impact resistance provides an assessment of the effects of impacts from falling objects which can either tear or weaken the geomembrane. As with the previous mechanical properties, there are various ASTM methods for assessment. Significantly higher impact resistances are realized when [[geotextiles]] are placed above or below the [[geomembrane]]. Thicker geomembranes also display higher impact resistances.<ref name="sharma"/>
=== Puncture resistance === Puncture resistance of a geomembrane is important due to the heterogeneous material above and below a typical liner. Rough surfaces, such as stones or other sharp objects, may puncture a membrane if it does not have sufficient puncture resistance. Various methods beyond standard ASTM tests are available; one such method, the critical cone height test, measures the maximum height of a cone on which a compressed geomembrane, which is subjected to increasing pressure, does not fail. HDPE samples typically have a critical cone height of around 1 cm.<ref>Kolbasuk, G. 1991. Coextruded Hdpe Vldpe Multilayer Geomembranes. Geotextiles and Geomembranes. 10, no. 5-6: 601-612.</ref>
=== Environmental stress cracking === Environmental stress cracking is defined as external or internal cracking in plastic induced by applied tensile stress less than its short-term tensile strength. ESC is a fairly common observation in HDPE geomembranes and thus needs to be evaluated carefully. Proper polymeric properties, such as molecular weight, orientation, and distribution, aid in ESC resistance. ASTM D5397 [standard test method for evaluation of stress crack resistance of polyolefin geomembranes using notched constant tensile load (NCTL)] provides the necessary procedure for measuring the ESC resistance of most HDPE geomembranes. The current recommended transition time for an acceptable HDPE geomembrane is around 100 h.<ref name="sharma"/>
==See also== *[[Bioclogging]] *[[Biogas]] *[[Daily cover]] *[[Landfill mining]] *[[Landfills in the United States]] *[[Waste compaction]]
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==External links==

revision.comment: Added reference to MOPP (electrical safety); makes me wonder at which point an MOPP disambiguation page would be in order.
revision.text:
{{for|the chemotherapy regimen|MOPP (chemotherapy)}} {{for|the medical concept|MOPP (electrical safety)}} [[Image:MOPP 4 high res.JPEG|thumb|right|200px|U.S. Marines in MOPP 4 gear during the [[2003 invasion of Iraq]]]] <!-- Unsourced image removed: [[Image:fullmopp.jpg|thumb|right|150px|Marines shown wearing MOPP 4 level gear]] -->
'''MOPP''' (an acronym for "'''Mission Oriented Protective Posture'''"; pronounced "mop") is protective gear used by U.S. [[military]] personnel in a toxic environment, e.g., during a chemical, biological, radiological, or nuclear ([[CBRN]]) strike:
* [[gas mask|Protective mask]] — Commonly referred to as a [[gas mask]] or pro mask. It is designed to filter harmful chemical and biological agents, as well as irradiated particles from the air to allow the wearer to breathe safely. No protective masks filter out gases such as [[carbon monoxide]], and in situations requiring that level of protection, external breathing apparatus is employed. * Mask carrier — Protects the mask from damage. It is usually worn as part of battle gear for easy access and usually contains a technical manual, extra filter, spare parts, chemical detection papers, and [[nerve agent]] [[antidote]] kits (NAAK). * Over garments — [[Joint Service Lightweight Integrated Suit Technology]] (JSLIST) Specially designed clothing to be worn over the normal uniform. These garments are designed to allow maximum airflow for cooling while keeping chemical and biological agents from reaching the [[skin]] of the wearer. Some are equipped with a [[charcoal]] lining to neutralize some agents. Military personnel often equip over garments with strips of [[M9 Detector Tape|M9 Detector Paper]] to identify chemical agents on the battlefield they might come in contact with. * M9 Detector paper is worn to detect chemical liquid agents that a service member may brush against while in MOPP gear. It is worn in three different area of the suit. It is worn on the dominant arm, bicep area, on the wrist of the opposite arm, and on the dominant leg, shin area. It is also placed on lower levels of vehicles for detection purposes.{{citation needed|date=September 2013}} * Gloves and overboots — (JSLIST) Highly durable [[rubber]], designed with combat operations in mind. Used to prevent contact with agents.
== MOPP protection levels == [[Image:TurkishFirefighterMOPP4.jpeg|thumb|right|200px|Turkish Firefighters in MOPP 4 level gear during an exercise held at [[Incirlik Air Base]], [[Turkey]]]] Each MOPP level corresponds to an increasing level of protection. The readiness level will usually be dictated by the in-theatre commander.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gulflink.osd.mil/khamisiyah_ii/khamisiyah_ii_refs/n15en246/Ch2.htm |title=FM 3-4 Chptr 2 MOPP Analysis |publisher=Gulflink.osd.mil |date=1990-05-23 |accessdate=2018-07-11}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.armystudyguide.com/content/army_board_study_guide_topics/cbrn/5-levels-of-mopp.shtml |title=5 Levels of MOPP |publisher=ArmyStudyGuide.com |date= |accessdate=2018-07-11}}</ref> *Mask Only - Protective mask is carried. *MOPP Ready — Protective mask is carried. First set of suit, gloves, and boots are available within two hours, second set within six hours. *MOPP Level 0 — Worn: nothing. Carried: Protective mask. Immediately Available: suit, boots and gloves. *MOPP Level 1 — Worn: suit. Carried: Protective mask. Immediately Available: boots and gloves *MOPP Level 2 — Worn: suit and boots. Carried: Protective mask and gloves. *MOPP Level 3 — Worn: suit, boots and mask. Carried: gloves. *MOPP Level 4 — All protection worn.
==See also== {{commonscat|MOPP}} * [[NBC suit]] * [[Fallout shelter]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.fas.org/nuke/guide/usa/doctrine/usaf/32401200.pdf Mission-Oriented Protective Postures (MOPP)]
{{U.S. chemical weapons}} {{U.S. biological defense}}

page.title: Ministry of Higher Education and Scientific Research (Jordan)

revision.text:
{{Infobox Government agency |agency_name = Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan
Ministry of Higher Education and Scientific Research
وزارة التعليم العالي والبحث العلمي |logo = Coat of Arms of Jordan.svg |logo_width = |logo_caption = [[Emblem of Jordan]] |seal = |seal_width = 150px |seal_caption = |formed = 1982 |preceding2 = |dissolved = |superseding = |jurisdiction = [[Jordan]] |headquarters = [[Jubaiha]], [[Amman]] {{flagicon|Jordan}} |employees = |budget = |chief1_name = azmi mahafzah |chief1_position = |chief2_name = |chief2_position = |child1_agency = |website = http://www.mohe.gov.jo/ |footnotes = }} The '''Ministry of Higher Education and Scientific Research ('''[[Arabic]]: وزارة التعليم العالي والبحث العلمي) is the government body that is responsible for maintaining and implementing government policies in higher education in [[Jordan]]. The ministry provides the support, services and organization aimed at guiding higher education sector in Jordan. ==History== The Council of Higher Education was established in 1982 in response to the increased demand of regulating and planning the policies of higher education. In 1985, the council was renamed to the Ministry of Higher Education. The ministry was annulled and was merged within the Ministry of Education in 1998, but was re-established in 2001 and was renamed as the Ministry of Higher Education and Scientific Research.[http://eacea.ec.europa.eu/tempus/participating_countries/higher/jordan.pdf Europe- Tempus report on Jordan] ==Scientific Research== The ministry following its re-establishment in 2001, was given a new responsibility of guiding the scientific research sector of higher education in [[Jordan]]. In 2005, the Scientific Research Committee was formed. Since 2006, the ministry issues several internationally peer-reviewed journals in cooperation with several Jordanian universities: # [[Jordan Journal of Mechanical and Industrial Engineering|Jordan Journal of Mechanical and Industrial Engineering (JJMIE)]] [http://jjmie.hu.edu.jo/ Jordan Journal of Mechanical and Industrial Engineering (JJMIE)] published in cooperation with the Deanship of Graduate Studies and Scientific Research in the [[Hashemite University]]. # [[Jordan Journal of Biological Sciences (JJBS)|Jordan Journal of Biological Sciences]] [http://jjbs.hu.edu.jo/ Jordan Journal of Biological Sciences (JJBS)] The Journal is published in cooperation with the [[Hashemite University]]. {{ISSN|1995-6673}} # [[Jordan Journal of Chemistry| Jordan Journal of Chemistry (JJC)]].[http://www.jjc.yu.edu.jo/index.html Jordan Journal of Chemistry (JJC)] Published in cooperation with the Deanship of Research and Graduate Studies in [[Yarmouk University]]. ({{ISSN|1814-9111}}) # [[Jordan Journal of Civil Engineering| Jordan Journal of Civil Engineering (JJCE)]].[http://www.just.edu.jo/jjce/index.htm Jordan Journal of Civil Engineering (JJCE)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090112212920/http://www.just.edu.jo/jjce/index.htm |date=2009-01-12 }} Published in cooperation with [[Jordan University of Science and Technology]]. # [[Jordan Journal of Earth and Environmental Sciences| Jordan Journal of Earth and Environmental Sciences (JJEES)]].[http://jjees.hu.edu.jo/ Jordan Journal of Earth and Environmental Sciences (JJEES)] Published in cooperation with the [[Hashemite University]]. # [[Jordan Journal of Physics|Jordan Journal of Physics (JJP)]] [http://journals.yu.edu.jo/jjp/index.html Jordan Journal of Physics (JJP)] published with [[Yarmouk University]]. ({{ISSN|1994-7615}}) # [[Jordan Journal of Modern Languages and Literature]] [http://journals.yu.edu.jo/jjmll/ Jordan Journal of Modern Languages and Literature (JJMLL)] published with [[Yarmouk University]]. ({{ISSN|1994-6953}}) # [[Jordan Journal of Educational Sciences| Jordan Journal of Educational Sciences (JJES)]] [http://journals.yu.edu.jo/jjes/ Jordan Journal of Educational Sciences (JJES)] published in cooperation with [[Yarmouk University]]. ({{ISSN|1814-9480}}) # [[Jordan Journal of Arabic Language and Literature]]المجلة الأردنية في اللغة العربية وآدابها [http://www.mutah.edu.jo/dar/jjour.htm Jordan Journal of Arabic Language and Literature] a journal in [[Arabic]] language published with [[Mu'tah University]]. ==References== ==External links== * [http://www.mohe.gov.jo/ MOHE website] [[Category:1982 establishments in Jordan]] [[Category:Ministries established in 1982]] [[Category:Ministry of Higher Education and Scientific Research (Jordan)| ]] [[Category:Education in Jordan]] [[Category:Science and technology in Jordan]] [[Category:Government ministries of Jordan|Higher Education]]

revision.comment: Rescued 1 archive link; reformat 1 link. [[User:GreenC/WaybackMedic_2.1|Wayback Medic 2.1]]
revision.text:
'''Murray Goldberg''' (born October 1962) is a noted Canadian [[educational technologist]] and a faculty member in the Department of Computer Science at the [[University of British Columbia]] in Vancouver, Canada. Goldberg is best known for being the founder of the [[elearning]] companies [[WebCT]], [[Brainify]], [[Silicon Chalk]], [[AssociCom]], and [[Marine Learning Systems]]. Goldberg was born in [[Calgary]], [[Alberta]], [[Canada]] and raised in [[Edmonton]] until he moved to [[British Columbia]] to attend the [[University of Victoria]] in 1980. Murray graduated from UVic in 1985 and then went on to earn an MSc from the [[University of British Columbia]]. In 2004 he was awarded an honorary Ph.D. from the Southern Cross University.<ref name="NewMedia">[http://www.maltwood.uvic.ca/nmc/2001/program/press_releases.html#teaching ''Murray Goldberg & WebCT Wins Hyperion Award'']</ref> Murray serves as director for various companies, sits on the board of trustees of Harvey Mudd College in Claremont California, is a mentor at the GSV Labs tech incubator in Redwood City California, and is a frequent consultant and speaker on the future of eLearning. Murray is also the chair of the British Columbia chapter of the [[Manning Innovation Awards]].
==Professional History==
===University of British Columbia===
Murray began as a faculty member in the Department of Computer Science at UBC in 1993 and was awarded tenure there in 1998.<ref name="checs">[http://www.checs.net/checs_99/GoldbergFrameset.html ''Goldberg short speaker biography'', New Mexico CHECS]</ref> In 1994, his first year as a faculty member at UBC, Goldberg won the [https://web.archive.org/web/20090312005022/http://vpacademic.ubc.ca/awards/killam/index.htm Killiam Teaching Prize] at UBC.<ref name="killiam">[http://www.vpacademic.ubc.ca/awards/killam/winners.htm#1993 Killiam Teaching Prize Award Winners] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081222192301/http://www.vpacademic.ubc.ca/awards/killam/winners.htm |date=2008-12-22 }}</ref> Goldberg took a leave of absence from UBC in 1998 to lead WebCT full-time.<ref>[http://www.cs.ubc.ca/about/Reports/annual/annual2001/Department_Highlights.html ''UBC Computer Science Department Highlights'', 1998/1999] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20050922044809/http://www.cs.ubc.ca/about/Reports/annual/annual2001/Department_Highlights.html |date=2005-09-22 }}</ref>
===WebCT=== In 1995, as a UBC faculty member, Goldberg was researching the effectiveness of Web-Based learning environments.<ref name="calos1">[http://portal.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=236462.236534 ''CALOS: an experiment with computer-aided learning for operating systems''], Proceedings of the twenty-seventh SIGCSE technical symposium on Computer science education, p.175-179, February 15–17, 1996, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, United States</ref><ref name="calos2">[http://portal.acm.org/citation.cfm?doid=268085.268101 ''CALOS: first results from an experiment in computer-aided learning for operating systems''], Proceedings of the twenty-eighth SIGCSE technical symposium on Computer science education, p.48-52, February 27-March 01, 1997, San Jose, California, United States</ref> Goldberg found that the experience of building the courses for this experimentation was sufficiently time consuming and expensive that he decided to create a platform to enable the simple and rapid creation of web-based learning environments,<ref name="synergy">[http://www.science.ubc.ca/sites/science.ubc.ca/files/synergy/2-1.pdf ''Goldberg Pioneers On-Line Education'', Synergy Magazine, Issue 2.1, October 1996]</ref><ref name="NYT">[https://www.nytimes.com/2000/12/21/technology/21TEAC.html ''College Courses Taught with Tailored Software'', The New York Times, December 21st, 2000]</ref> WebCT. WebCT was widely accepted as a catalyst in the worldwide boom of on-line learning that accelerated beginning in 1997.<ref name = "SCMP">''What you see is Now What You Get Taught'', South China Morning Post, November 18, 2000</ref> By November, 2000 WebCT was purportedly serving 6 million students in 57 countries,<ref name="SCMP" /> and by late 2001, 10 million students in 80 countries at 2250 universities and colleges.<ref name="courier">[http://archive.vancourier.com/issues01/06501-1/news/06501-1N11.html ''UBC prof leads Web education revolution'', The Vancouver Courier, June 28, 2001] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20110717184607/http://archive.vancourier.com/issues01/06501-1/news/06501-1N11.html |date=July 17, 2011 }}</ref> In 1999, Goldberg sold most of his stake in WebCT to Boston-Based Universal Learning Technology. The combined company took on the WebCT name.<ref name="NYT" /><ref name="globe">[https://www.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/Page/document/v5/content/subscribe?user_URL=https://www.theglobeandmail.com%2Fservlet%2Fstory%2FLAC.20000131.RUBCC%2FTPStory%2F%3Fquery%3DFinds%2BVirtual%2BSuccess&ord=16684550&brand=theglobeandmail&force_login=true ''BC University Spinoff Finds Virtual Success'', The Globe and Mail, January 31, 2000]</ref> Goldberg remained as president of the Canadian division of WebCT until 2002 when he left to co-found [[Silicon Chalk]].
===Silicon Chalk=== In 2002 Goldberg co-founded Silicon Chalk and served as the president and CEO.<ref>[http://ausweb.scu.edu.au/aw04/conf/keynotes.html AUSWEB Keynote Speaker Biographical Details]</ref> Silicon Chalk created software for use in laptop or computer enabled higher education classrooms. The software facilitated the recording of classroom presentations, student note taking, polling, file sharing, and other features.<ref>[http://www.editlib.org/p/13712 ''Silicon Chalk – Supporting Learning in the Classroom and Beyond'']</ref> The company never achieved widespread success, though did have users in 70 universities and colleges when it was sold to [[Horizon Wimba]]<ref>[http://staff.blog.ui.edu/harrybs/2008/07/ ''History of Virtual Learning Environments''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090316114624/http://staff.blog.ui.edu/harrybs/2008/07/ |date=2009-03-16 }}</ref>
===Brainify=== In 2007 Goldberg began work on [[Brainify]][https://web.archive.org/web/20090204164850/http://brainify.com/ (website)], an academic social bookmarking and networking site for university and college students and professors.<ref>[http://chronicle.com/free/2009/01/10124n.htm ''Social Bookmarking Site for Higher Education Makes Debut'', The Chronicle of Higher Education]</ref> Brainify was launched in January 2009 and Goldberg acts as the President and CEO. Members from 250 institutions had joined within the first 20 days of its launch.<ref>[https://archive.is/20110610175443/http://www.dailytargum.com/university/1.1480886-1.1480886 ''Interactive Website digitally links colleges'']</ref>
===AssociCom=== In June, 2010, Goldberg launched [[AssociCom]] [http://www.associcom.com (website)], a professional networking and discovery platform with an emphasis on enabling member discovery, learning and connection within professional associations and societies.<ref>[http://www.associcom.com/Home/What ''What is AssociCom'']. Murray stepped down as CEO of the company to focus full time on [[Marine Learning Systems]], though he continues to be involved as the chair of the board of directors.</ref>
===Marine Learning Systems=== Also in 2010, Murray founded the company [[Marine Learning Systems]] [http://www.marinels.com (website)]. Their product, MarineLMS, is a learning management system for training in the maritime industry, with [[BC Ferries]] as their first customer.<ref>[http://worldmaritimenews.com/archives/34014 ''Canada: First Learning Management System for Maritime Training Released'', World Maritime News]</ref>
==Selected Awards and Distinctions== * 2011 - ''Murray Goldberg named as one of the top 15 Canadians in Digital Media'' <ref>[http://www.backbonemag.com/Magazine/2011-11/top-15-canadians-in-digital-media.aspx ''Backbone Magazines Top 15 Canadians in Digital Media''] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111210012935/http://www.backbonemag.com/Magazine/2011-11/top-15-canadians-in-digital-media.aspx |date=2011-12-10 }}.</ref> * 2004 - ''Murray Goldberg awarded the $100,000 National [[Manning Innovation Awards]] Principal Award for Innovation''. This is a National award, awarded once per year for innovation in any human endeavor<ref>[http://www.manningawards.ca/awards/winners/mgoldberg.shtml ''Manning Innovation Awards Principal Award Winner for 2004''].</ref> Award video can be found [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eFipG7cdiOM here]. * 2004 - ''Murray Goldberg granted an Honorary Ph.D.'', Southern Cross University, Gold Coast, Australia<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.scu.edu.au/governance/council/index.php/9/ |title=Honorary Awards at the Southern Cross University: Doctor of Technology |access-date=2009-03-01 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110303090506/http://www.scu.edu.au/governance/council/index.php/9/ |archive-date=2011-03-03 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> * 2001 – ''Murray Goldberg awarded the New Media Hyperion Award''. This award for excellence is awarded annually to those who have made a significant contribution in the creation or development of software tools, hardware or connectivity innovations.<ref name="NewMedia" /> * 2000 – ''Murray Goldberg awarded the National CANARIE IWAY Award''. This is a national award, awarded to nominees who have pioneered innovative uses of technology related to the development of Canada's information highway.<ref>[http://www.canarie.ca/iway/guide.html CANARIE IWAY Awards] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071116053053/http://www.canarie.ca/iway/guide.html |date=2007-11-16 }}</ref> * 1994 - ''Murray Goldberg awarded the "Killiam Teaching Prize"''. These prizes, accompanied by a monetary award, are given annually at UBC to a small number of faculty members who have exhibited excellence in teaching.<ref>[http://www.vpacademic.ubc.ca/awards/killam/index.htm UBC Killiam Teaching Prizes] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090312005022/http://vpacademic.ubc.ca/awards/killam/index.htm |date=2009-03-12 }}</ref>
==External links== * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QlWoefy5B0w Video of Murray Goldberg presenting WebCT at CICEI in 1998]
==Notes and references== <references/>

revision.text:
'''Polysilicon depletion effect''' is the phenomenon in which unwanted variation of [[threshold voltage]] of the [[MOSFET]] devices using [[polysilicon]] as gate material is observed, leading to unpredicted behaviour of the [[electronic circuit]].{{cite journal |last1=Rios |first1=R. |last2=Arora |first2=N.D. |year=1994 |title=An analytic polysilicon depletion effect model for MOSFETs |journal=Electron Device Letters, IEEE |volume=15 |issue=4 |pages=129–131 |publisher=IEEE |doi= |url=http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/xpl/login.jsp?tp=&arnumber=285407&url=http%3A%2F%2Fieeexplore.ieee.org%2Fxpls%2Fabs_all.jsp%3Farnumber%3D285407 |accessdate=7 June 2013}} Polycrystalline silicon, also called [[polysilicon]], is a material consisting of small silicon crystals. It differs from [[single-crystal silicon]], used for electronics and [[solar cells]], and from amorphous silicon, used for thin film devices and solar cells. ==Gate material choice== The gate contact may be of [[polysilicon]] or metal, previously polysilicon was chosen over metal because the interfacing between polysilicon and [[gate oxide]] ([[Silicon dioxide|SiO2]]) was favourable. But the conductivity of the poly-silicon layer is very low and because of this low conductivity, the charge accumulation is low, leading to a delay in channel formation and thus unwanted delays in circuits. The poly layer is doped with N-type or P-type impurity to make it behave like a perfect conductor and reduce the delay. ==Doped polysilicon gate disadvantages== [[File:Without application of any field.png|thumb|left|Figure 1(a)]] ''Vgs = Gate Voltage
Vth = Threshold Voltage
N+ = Highly doped N region'' In ''figure 1(a)'' it is observed that the free [[majority carriers]] are scattered throughout the structure because of the absence of an external [[electric field]]. When a positive field is applied on the gate, the scattered carriers arrange themselves like ''figure 1(b)'', the electrons move closer toward the gate terminal but due to the open circuit configuration they don't start to flow. As a result of the separation of charges a depletion region is formed on the polysilicon-oxide interface, which has a direct effect on the channel formation{{cite journal |last1=Rios |first1=R. |last2=Arora |first2=N.D. |year=1994 |title=Modeling the polysilicon depletion effect and its impact on submicrometer CMOS circuit performance |journal=Electron Devices, IEEE Transactions |volume=42 |issue=5 |pages=935–943 |publisher=IEEE |doi= |url=http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/xpl/freeabs_all.jsp?arnumber=381991 |accessdate=7 June 2013}} in [[MOSFET]]. [[File:With application of field.png|thumb|Figure 1(b)]] In an NMOS with n+ Polysilicon gate, the poly depletion effect aids in the channel formation by the combined effect of the ''(+)ve'' field of donor ions (ND) and the externally applied ''(+)ve'' field at gate terminal. Basically the accumulation of the ''(+)ve'' charged Donor [[ions]] (ND) on the polysilicon enhances the Formation of the inversion channel and when Vgs > Vth an inversion layer is formed, which can be seen in the figure 1(b) where the inversion channel is formed of acceptor ions (NA)([[minority carriers]]).{{cite conference |url=http://www.eecs.berkeley.edu/~hu/PUBLICATIONS/Hu_papers/Hu_CNF/HuC_CNF_085.pdf |title=Impact of polysilicon depletion in thin oxide MOS technology |last1=Schuegraf |first1=K.F. |authorlink1= |last2=King |first2=C.C.|last3=Hu |first3=C. |year=1993 |publisher= |booktitle=Proceedings International Symposium: VLSI Technology Systems and Applications |pages=86–90 |location= |id= }} Polysilicon depletion can vary laterally across a transistor depending on the fabrication process, which can lead to significant transistor variability in certain transistor dimensions.H. P. Tuinhout, A. H. Montree, J. Schmitz and P. A. Stolk, Effects of gate depletion and boron penetration on matching of deep submicron CMOS transistors, IEEE International Electron Device Meeting, Technical Digest pp. 631-634, 1997. ==Metal gate contacts re-introduced== For the above reason as the devices go down on the scaling [[32nm|(32-28nm nodes)]] poly gates are being replaced by metal gates. The following technology is known as High-k Dielectric Metal Gate (HKMG) integration.[http://globalfoundries.com/technology/32-28nm.aspx Global Foundries] Recently, [[Intel]] also released a press-kit regarding their fabrication procedures of different nodes, which showed the use of Metal gate technology.{{cite press release |last= |first= |title=From Sand to Silicon: The Making of Chip |trans-title=|date=Nov 11, 2011 |publisher=Intel Technology |location= |url=http://newsroom.intel.com/docs/DOC-2476 |format= |accessdate=2013-06-08 |archiveurl= |archivedate=2013-06-08 |deadurl= |quote= |ref= }} Doped polysilicon was preferred earlier as gate material in MOS devices. Polysilicons were used as their [[work function]] matched with the Si substrate (which results in the low [[threshold voltage]] of [[MOSFET]]). Metal gates were re-introduced at the time when SiO2 [[dielectric]]s are being replaced by [[high-k dielectric]]s like [[Hafnium oxide]] as gate oxide in the mainstream [[CMOS]] technology.{{cite press release |last=Chau |first=Robert |title=Gate Dielectric Scaling for CMOS: from SiO2/PolySi to High-K/Metal-Gate |trans-title=|date=Nov 6, 2003 |publisher=Intel Technology |location= |url=http://www.intel.com/content/www/us/en/silicon-innovations/gate-dielectric-scaling-for-cmos-guide.html|format=White paper |accessdate=2013-06-08 |archiveurl= |archivedate=2013-06-08 |deadurl= |quote= |ref= }} Also at the interface with gate dielectric, Polysilicon forms an SiOx layer. Moreover, there remains a high probability for [[Fermi level pinning]] to occur.{{cite journal |last1=Hobbs |first1=C.C. |last2=Fonseca |first2=L. R. C.|last3=Knizhnik |first3= A. |year=2004 |title=Fermi-level pinning at the polysilicon/metal oxide interface-Part I |journal=Electron Devices, IEEE Transactions on |volume=51 |issue=6 |pages=971–977 |publisher=IEEE |doi= |url=http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/xpl/freeabs_all.jsp?arnumber=1300833 |accessdate=7 June 2013}} So the effect with doped poly is an undesired reduction of threshold voltage that wasn't taken into account during circuit simulation. In order to avoid this kind of variation in [[Threshold voltage|vth]] of the [[MOSFET]], at present metal gate is preferred over [[Polysilicon]]. ==See also== {{div col}} *[https://dx.doi.org/10.1149/1.1632873 Reduction of Polysilicon Gate Depletion Effect in NMOS] *[[DIBL|Drain-induced barrier lowering]] *[[MOSFET#Gate material|Gate material]] *[http://blogs.intel.com/jobs/2012/02/28/from-sand-to-silicon-the-making-of-a-chip Fabrication of microprocessor by intel] {{div col end}} == References == {{Reflist}} [[Category:Transistors]] [[Category:Semiconductor devices]] [[Category:Semiconductor technology]]

{{Unreferenced|date=December 2007}} [[Image:Remingtonlogo.jpg|thumb|250px|Old Remington Logo]] '''Remington Products''', commonly known as simply '''Remington''', is a worldwide [[personal care]] corporation which manufactures razors (shavers), [[epilator]]s, and [[haircare]] products for both men and women. It is a subsidiary of [[Spectrum Brands]] and [[Oak Hill Capital]].
==History==
The origins of the "Remington" name date back to the formation of '''[[E. Remington and Sons]]''', a [[firearms]] maker founded in 1816. E. Remington & Sons made occasional forays into products other than firearms, such as [[sewing machine]]s and [[farm implement]]s — but its most significant side venture was when inventor [[Christopher Sholes]] persuaded the firearms company to help him develop the [[typewriter]] with the [[QWERTY]] [[Alphanumeric keyboard|keyboard]], which is still the standard today. In 1886, E. Remington & Sons sold the typewriter company, which became Remington Typewriter Company. This in turn merged with the Rand Kardex Corporation in 1927 to become [[Remington Rand]]. Remington Rand branched out into making [[adding machine]]s, [[filing cabinet]]s, [[punched card]] tabulating machines, and other [[office equipment]] to become a leading office equipment company.
The origin of Remington personal care products dates back to 1937 when Remington Rand began to branch out to [[electric shaver]]s, starting with the Remington Model E.
In 1950, Remington Rand bought the pioneering [[Eckert-Mauchly Computer Corporation|Eckert-Mauchly Computer Company]]. In 1955, it merged with [[Sperry Corporation]], developer of the [[autopilot|automatic pilot]], amongst other [[Machine|device]]s. The combined company became the [[Sperry Rand Corporation]] and continued to market shavers under the Remington brand. In 1979, Sperry Rand sold off a number of its divisions, including the consumer products. [[Victor Kiam]] bought the electric shaver company in a [[leveraged buyout]].
Victor Kiam's '''Remington Products Company''' became very profitable, branching out into other personal care [[small appliance]]s, buying [[Clairol]]'s personal care appliance business in 1994. Kiam sold [[controlling interest]] in Remington to [[Ike Perlmutter]] prior to the Clairol [[Takeover|acquisition]] that same year. Remington changed hands again on June 1996 when Perlmutter and Kiam sold controlling interest in the company to [[Vestar Capital Partners]]. Victor Kiam died in 2001. In 2003, the Kiam family and Vestar sold Remington to the [[Battery (electricity)|battery]] company [[Rayovac]]. Rayovac changed its name to [[Spectrum Brands]] and [[Marketing|market]]s Remington brand men's and [http://www.remingtonproducts.com/products/womens/hair-removal.aspx women's electric shavers], [[hair clipper]]s, [[beard]] and [[moustache]] [[Hair clipper|trimmers]], [https://shavingbeast.com/best-nose-trimmers-for-men-in-2017 nose and ear hair trimmers], [[foot massage]]rs, [[make-up]] [[mirror]]s, heated hair rollers, [[blow dryer]]s, and [[curling iron]]s. Remington also sells [[hair straighteners|flat irons]].
==Products== {{Expand section|date=June 2008}} Air Plates, ProLuxe, Rose Pearl, Keratin Radiance, Wet2Straight, Shine therapy, Colour protect, Ceramic 210, Ceramic Slim 230, Pro ceramic Extra, Protect Sleek and Smooth
Remington Products' product line include '''Lady Remington'''s, electric shavers for women.
== TV commercials== The president of Remington shavers in 1978: "When my wife bought me a Remington shaver, I was so impressed I bought the company". [[Victor Kiam]] would often appear in television advertisements for Remington shavers and say: "Shaves as close as a blade, or your money back!"{{cn|date=July 2017}}
==External links== * [http://www.remingtonproducts.com Official site]
[[Category:Hair removal]] [[Category:Manufacturing companies of the United States]] [[Category:Personal care brands]] [[Category:Shaving]]

revision.text:
{{coord|37|47|07|N|122|23|48|W|display=title|type:landmark_region:US-CA}} [[File:Picture 001-small.jpg|thumb|align=right|300px|Photograph of Room 641's exterior]] {{NSA surveillance|1}} {{Global surveillance}} '''Room 641A''' is a telecommunication interception facility operated by [[AT&T]] for the U.S. [[National Security Agency]] that commenced operations in 2003 and was exposed in 2006.<ref name=WiredEvidence /><ref name=wired1/>
==Description== Room 641A is located in the [[SBC Communications]] building at 611 Folsom Street, [[San Francisco]], three floors of which were occupied by AT&T before SBC purchased AT&T.<ref name=WiredEvidence /> The room was referred to in internal AT&T documents as the ''SG3 [Study Group 3] Secure Room.'' It is fed by [[optical fiber|fiber optic]] lines from [[beam splitter]]s installed in fiber optic trunks carrying [[Internet backbone]] traffic<ref name=kleinex /> and, as analyzed by J. Scott Marcus, a former [[Chief technology officer|CTO]] for [[GTE]] and a former adviser to the [[Federal Communications Commission|FCC]], has access to all Internet traffic that passes through the building, and therefore "the capability to enable surveillance and analysis of internet content on a massive scale, including both overseas and purely domestic traffic."<ref name=marcus1 />
The room measures about {{convert|24|by|48|ft}} and contains several racks of equipment, including a [[Narus (company)|Narus]] STA 6400, a device designed to intercept and analyze Internet communications at very high speeds.<ref name=WiredEvidence/>
The existence of the room was revealed by former AT&T technician [[Mark Klein]] and was the subject of a 2006 [[class action]] lawsuit by the [[Electronic Frontier Foundation]] against AT&T.<ref name=EFFdocs/> Klein claims he was told that similar [[black room]]s are operated at other facilities around the country.{{Citation needed|date=March 2018}}
Room 641A and the controversies surrounding it were subjects of an episode of ''[[Frontline (U.S. TV series)|Frontline]]'',<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/homefront/view/|title=Spying on the Homefront|work=Frontline|publisher=PBS|accessdate=2013-08-01}}</ref> the current affairs documentary program on [[Public Broadcasting Service|PBS]]. It was originally broadcast on May 15, 2007. It was also featured on PBS's ''[[NOW on PBS|NOW]]'' on March 14, 2008. The room was also covered in the PBS ''[[Nova (TV series)|Nova]]'' episode "The Spy Factory".
==Lawsuit== {{main|Hepting v. AT&T}} The [[Electronic Frontier Foundation]] (EFF) filed a [[Class action|class-action]] [[lawsuit]] against [[AT&T]] on January 31, 2006, accusing the telecommunication company of violating the law and the privacy of its customers by collaborating with the [[National Security Agency]] (NSA) in a massive, illegal program to [[wiretap]] and [[Data mining|data-mine]] Americans' communications. On July 20, 2006, a federal judge denied the government's and AT&T's motions to dismiss the case, chiefly on the ground of the [[State Secrets Privilege|States Secrets Privilege]], allowing the lawsuit to go forward. On August 15, 2007, the case was heard by the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit|Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals]] and was dismissed on December 29, 2011 based on a [[Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act of 1978 Amendments Act of 2008|retroactive grant of immunity]] by Congress for telecommunications companies that cooperated with the government. The U.S. Supreme Court declined to hear the case.<ref name="eff-hepting">{{cite web|url=https://www.eff.org/cases/hepting |title=Hepting v. AT&T | Electronic Frontier Foundation |publisher=Eff.org |date=2006-01-31 |accessdate=2014-02-12}}</ref> A different case by the EFF was filed on September 18, 2008, titled ''[[Jewel v. NSA]]''.
==Gallery== <gallery> File:SER marcus decl.djvu|page=17|Page 17: Basic diagram of how the alleged wiretapping was accomplished. From [[Electronic Frontier Foundation|EFF]] court filings<ref name=marcus1 /> File:SER klein exhibits.djvu|page=9|Page 9: More complicated diagram of how it allegedly worked. From EFF court filings.<ref name=kleinex/> File:Fiber optic tap.png|A fiber optic tap. </gallery>
==See also== {{Portal|San Francisco Bay Area|Government of the United States|Intelligence}} * [[Cabinet noir]] * [[ECHELON]] * [[Fairview (surveillance program)]] * [[Fiber tapping]] * [[Hemisphere Project]], mass surveillance program conducted by AT&T and paid for by the DEA. * [[Main Core]] * [[NSA warrantless surveillance controversy]] * [[President's Surveillance Program]] * [[PRISM (surveillance program)]] * [[Signals intelligence]] * [[Upstream collection]] * [[Utah Data Center]]
==References== {{reflist|30em|refs= <ref name=wired1>{{cite news | title = The NSA Is Building the Country’s Biggest Spy Center (Watch What You Say) | first = James | last = [https://www.wired.com/threatlevel/author/james-bamford/ Bamford]
| url = https://www.wired.com/threatlevel/2012/03/ff_nsadatacenter/all/1 | newspaper = [[Wired (magazine)|Wired]] | date = 15 March 2012 | accessdate = 23 April 2012 }}</ref>
<ref name=WiredEvidence>{{cite journal |url = http://www.wired.com/science/discoveries/news/2006/05/70908 |title = AT&T Whistle-Blower's Evidence |journal = Wired |date = May 17, 2006 |accessdate = February 27, 2009 |deadurl = bot: unknown |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140328094710/http://www.wired.com/science/discoveries/news/2006/05/70908 |archivedate = March 28, 2014 |df = }}</ref>
<ref name=EFFdocs>{{cite web |url=https://www.eff.org/cases/att |title=NSA Multi-District Litigation |publisher=Electronic Frontier Foundation |accessdate=February 27, 2009 }}</ref>
<ref name=marcus1> "Marcus Declaration" Document from Hepting vs AT&T lawsuit from 2006. Reported by Ryan Singel in Wired Magazine, article [https://www.wired.com/politics/law/news/2007/06/spy_room "AT&T 'Spy Room' Documents Unsealed; You've Already Seen Them"] 6/13/07 , Documents posted at the Electronic Frontier Foundation [http://eff.org/legal/cases/att File "SER marcus decl.pdf website] (PDF)</ref>
<ref name=kleinex> "Klein Exhibit" Document from Hepting vs AT&T lawsuit from 2007. Reported by Ryan Singel in Wired Magazine, article [https://www.wired.com/politics/law/news/2007/06/spy_room "AT&T 'Spy Room' Documents Unsealed; You've Already Seen Them"] 6/13/07, Documents posted at the Electronic Frontier Foundation [http://eff.org/legal/cases/att File "SER_klein_exhibits.pdf website] (PDF)</ref> }}
==External links== *{{cite web |title=Electronic Frontier Foundation's web page about NSA's domestic spying |url=https://www.eff.org/nsa-spying }} *{{cite web |title=Technician Mark Klein discussing Room 641A |work=[[Countdown with Keith Olbermann|Countdown]] episode |date=November 7, 2007 |via=[[YouTube]] |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QP2tKBtUpVg |archivedate=February 2, 2009 |archiveurl=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=44edsh6_LUc }}
{{AT&T}} {{National Security Agency}}

Bush administration controversies]] [[Category:History of cryptography]] [[Category:Locations in the history of espionage]] [[Category:National Security Agency facilities]] [[Category:Privacy of telecommunications]] [[Category:Signals intelligence]] [[Category:Privacy in the United States]] [[Category:Organizations based in San Francisco]] [[Category:Individual rooms]]
