revision.text:
{{other uses of|Rustication}} [[image:Palazzo medici riccardi, bugnato 01.JPG|thumb|Two different styles of rustication in the [[Palazzo Medici-Riccardi]] in [[Florence]]; smooth-faced above and rough-faced below.]] [[File:Château de Fontainebleau 2011 (200).JPG|thumb|Extreme [[Mannerist]] "cyclopian" rustication at the [[Palace of Fontainebleau]]]]
In [[classical architecture]] '''rustication''' is a range of [[masonry]] techniques giving visible surfaces a finish that contrasts in texture with the smoothly finished, squared-block masonry surfaces called [[ashlar]]. The visible face of each individual block is cut back around the edges to make its size and placing very clear. In addition the central part of the face of each block may be given a deliberately rough or patterned surface.<ref>Summerson, 45-47, 58-59, 132</ref>
Rusticated masonry is usually "dressed", or squared off neatly, on all sides of the stones except the face that will be visible when the stone is put in place. This is given wide joints that emphasize the edges of each block, by angling the edges ("channel-jointed"), or dropping them back a little. The main part of the exposed face may be worked flat and smooth or left with, or worked, to give a more or less rough or patterned surface. Rustication is often used to give visual weight to the ground floor in contrast to smooth ashlar above. Though intended to convey a "rustic" simplicity, the finish is highly artificial, and the faces of the stones often carefully worked to achieve an appearance of a coarse finish.<ref>Summerson, 45-47</ref>
Rustication was used in ancient times, but became especially popular in the revived classical styles of [[Italian Renaissance architecture]] and that of subsequent periods, above all in the lower floors of secular buildings. It remains in use in some modern architecture.
Similar finishes are very common in medieval architecture, especially in [[castle]]s, walls and similar buildings, but here it merely arises from an unwillingness to spend the extra money required for ashlar masonry in a particular building, and lacks the deliberate emphasis on the joints between blocks. Though it often achieves a decorative effect, this is something of a by-product, and the exploitation for architectural effect within a single building of contrasts between rusticated and ashlar surfaces is rarely seen. In some buildings, such as the [[Palazzo Vecchio]] in [[Florence]] (begun 1298) something other than cost-saving is at play, and this may be the association of the technique with the display of power and strength, from its use in military architecture.<ref>Woodman</ref> Rough finishes on stone are also very common in architecture outside the European tradition, but these too would generally not be called rustication. For example, the bases of [[Japanese castle]]s and other fortifications usually use rough stone, often very attractively.
==History== [[File:Serlio XXIX.jpg|thumb|left|Serlio, rusticated doorway of the type now called a [[Gibbs surround]], 1537]] Although rustication is known from a few buildings of Greek and Roman antiquity, for example Rome's [[Porta Maggiore]], the method first became popular during the [[Renaissance]], when the stone work of lower floors and sometimes entire [[facade]]s of buildings were finished in this manner.<ref>Summerson, 58; Woodman. There is much detail in Alfonso Acocella, [http://www.architetturadipietra.it/wp/?p=4952 "Greek and Roman rustication"], online re-edit of his section in ''Stone architecture. Ancient and modern constructive skills'', Milan, Skira-Lucense, 2006, pp. 624 ff.</ref> It was generally used for secular buildings, and has always remained uncommon in churches, perhaps through a lingering association with the architecture of military power; there are exceptions, such as [[St Giles in the Fields]], London (1730–34).
Probably the earliest and most influential example is the [[Palazzo Medici Riccardi]] in [[Florence]], built between 1444 and 1484, with two contrasting rusticated finishes. The ground floor has an irregular and genuinely rugged appearance, with a variation in the degree to which parts of the faces of blocks project from the wall that is rarely equalled later. Above, the rustication is merely to emphasize the individual blocks, and the faces are all smooth and even. Also in Florence, [[Palazzo Strozzi]], begun 1489, with large oblong rounded cushions, and the front of the [[Pitti Palace]], begun 1458, rusticated their whole facades in the same style. These facades only used the [[classical order]]s in [[mullion]]s and [[aedicule]]s, with arched forms in rustication the main relief from the massive flat walls. The [[Palazzo Rucellai]], probably of the 1460s, begins to classicize such facades, using smooth-faced rustication throughout, except for the pilasters at each level.
In Rome, [[Donato Bramante]]'s [[Palazzo Caprini]] ("House of Raphael", by 1510, now destroyed) provided a standard model for the integration of rustication with the orders. Here the obvious strength of a blind arched [[arcade (architecture)|arcade]] with emphatic [[voussoir]]s on the rusticated ground storey (in fact using stucco) gave reassuring support to the upper storey's paired [[Doric order|Doric]] columns standing on rusticated [[pier (architecture)|piers]], set against a smooth wall.<ref>Summerson, 53</ref> The first major Renaissance building in Spain, the [[Palace of Charles V]] in [[Granada]] (1527), had a deeply rusticated ground floor facade with regular rounded cushions.
The technique was enthusiatically taken up by the next generation of [[Mannerist]] architects, with [[Giulio Romano]] in the lead. Most early examples of this "rustic" style are therefore built for sophisticated patrons in the leading centres of taste. Giulio's [[Palazzo Stati Maccarani]] in Rome and [[Palazzo Te]] in [[Mantua]] expand the voussoirs still further, and the courtyard in Mantua plays games with the technique, with some blocks ashlar, other projecting further than the rest, and larger blocks placed higher than smaller ones. The Mannerist architectural writer [[Sebastiano Serlio]] and others of his generation enjoyed the play between rusticated and finished architectural elements. In the woodcut of a doorway from Serlio's 1537 treatise, the banded rustication of the wall is carried right across the attached column and the moldings of the doorway surround, binding together all the elements. [[File:Somerset House courtyard (06).JPG|thumb|Courtyard of [[Somerset House]] in London, mostly smooth-faced "V" joints, but with vermiculated square blocks around the [[Gibbs surround]] to the door.]]
The Italians brought in to expand the [[Palace of Fontainebleau]] introduced the technique to France. Its spread to Germany and England took longer, but by about the end of the 16th century it had reached all parts of Europe. In his [[Banqueting House]] in London (1619), [[Inigo Jones]] gave a lightly rusticated surface texture to emphasize the blocks on both storeys, and to unify them behind his orders of pilasters and columns.
During the 18th century, following the [[Palladian]] revival, rustication was widely used on the ground floors of large buildings, as its contrived appearance of simplicity and solidity contrasted well to the carved ornamental stonework and columns of the floors above: "Rustication became almost obligatory in all 18th- and 19th-century public buildings in Europe and the USA".<ref>Woodman, exaggerating somewhat</ref> A ground floor with rustication, especially in an English mansion such as [[Kedleston Hall]], is sometimes referred to as the "rustic floor", in order to distinguish it from the [[piano nobile]] above. As well as uses emphasizing the horizontal, rustication is often used in relatively narrow vertical bands, on the [[quoin]]s at corners or elsewhere.<ref>Chitham, 126</ref> Rustication may also be confined to the surrounds of arches, doors or windows, especially at the top. In these and other situations where rustication stops horizontally, the edge is usually made up of vertically alternating long and short blocks.<ref>Chitham, 127</ref> Rustication therefore often reverses the patterns of medieval and later [[vernacular architecture]], where roughly dressed wall surfaces often contrast with ashlar quoins and frames to openings. [[File:Castle Howard, june 2011.JPG|thumb|left|Regular smooth-faced rustication (left) turns to horizontal banded rustication at the corner of [[Castle Howard]] in North Yorkshire, England.]]
Architectural books by authors such as [[James Gibbs]] and [[William Chambers (architect)|William Chambers]] set out detailed recommendations for the proportions of the blocks in relation to columns in the same facade, and the proportion of the block that a widened joint should occupy, though their prescriptions differ, and were not always followed by architects.<ref>Chitham, 126</ref>
Typically, rustication after 1700 is highly regular, with the front faces of blocks flat even when worked in patterns, as opposed to the real unevenness often seen in the 16th-century examples. Often the Palazzo Medici Riccardi model is followed; the ground floor has heavy rustication with textured faces, while above there is smooth-faced "V" rustication. Though such horizontal zones of rustication are the most common, vertical zones can often be used as highlights, as in the illustration from Catania above, or the Cour Napoleon in the [[Louvre Palace]]. The Baroque garden front of the [[Pitti Palace]] achieves a striking effect, not often copied, by using extensive "blocking", both rounded and rectangular, on the shafts of its columns and pilasters.
[[Canton Viaduct]], a blind arcade cavity wall railroad viaduct built in 1834-35 in [[Canton, Massachusetts]] is an example of modest effects of rustication in industrial architecture; the effect is pleasing, and the cost was probably reduced. Massive effects of contrasting rustications typify the "[[Richardsonian Romanesque]]" style exemplified in the 1870s and 80s by the American architect [[H. H. Richardson]]. The technique is still sometimes used in architecture of a broadly [[Modernist architecture|Modernist]] character, especially in city centre streets where it helps modern buildings blend with older ones with rustication.
Although essentially a technique for stone masonry, rustication can be imitated in brick and [[stucco]],<ref>Chitham, 126</ref> which began as early as [[Bramante]]'s [[Palazzo Caprini]] and was common in smaller houses in [[Georgian architecture]], and also in wood (see below), which is mainly found in [[British America]].
==Variations== [[File:Vermiculures.JPG|thumb|Two adjacent vermiculated blocks showing rather different interpretations of the pattern.]]
The most common variation of rustication is the smooth-faced, where the external face of the block is smooth, as in ashlar, and differs from that only by the cutting in at the joints; this became increasingly popular, and is now the most commonly seen type. If deeply cut-back edges are worked only to the horizontal joints, with the appearance of the vertical joints being minimised, the resulting effect is known as '''banded rustication''', mostly seen on the lowest levels of very large buildings like the [[Palace of Versailles]] or the main [[Foreign and Commonwealth Office|Foreign Office]] building in London. As at Versailles, the bands may de "elbowed", dipping diagonally around arches to join up with and emphasize the [[voussoir]]s. Banded rustication is mostly seen with smooth-faced stones, and has remained popular in [[Stripped Classicism]] and other contemporary versions of classical styles. In this style, the bands are sometimes several feet apart, making it apparent that stone facings are being used.
When the stone is left with a rough external surface, rough shapes may be drilled or chiselled in the somewhat smoothed face in a technique called "vermiculation" ('''vermiculate rustication''' or '''vermicular rustication'''), so called from the Latin ''vermiculus'' meaning "little worm",<ref>Woodman</ref> because the shapes resemble worms, worm-casts or worm tracks in mud or wet sand. Carved vermiculation requires a good deal of careful mason's work, and is mostly used over limited areas to highlight them. Disparities between individual blocks are often seen, presumably as different carvers interpreted their patterns slightly differently, or had different levels of skill.<ref>McKay, 38</ref> The small Turner Mausoleum at [[Kirkleatham]] by [[James Gibbs]] (1740) has an unusually large area vermiculated, over half of the main level. When the shapes join up to form a network, the style is called "reticulated".<ref>McKay, 38</ref>
Often, especially from the Baroque onwards, the roughly flattened central areas of stones are indented in regular, but not too regular, patterns called "pecked" or "picked-work", and various other ways of patterning them may be found. In garden architecture, where water was to flow over or near the surface, a vertically oriented pattern evoking hanging pond-weed or [[algae]], or [[icicle]]s ("frost-work") is sometimes used.<ref>[http://www.lookingatbuildings.org.uk/styles/classical/features/rustication.html Looking at buildings], "Rustication"</ref> Also associated with gardens is "cyclopian" rustication, where the blocks are very large and irregular, as though placed by giants, and "rock-work", where surfaces are built up of rough rocks not placed in regular courses at all. This last goes beyond rustication, and is found in fountains and follies, and later [[rockery|rockeries]] for planting.
In '''prismatic rustication''' the blocks are dressed at an angle near each edge, giving a [[Prism (geometry)|prism]]-like shape.<ref>"Prismatic", in Curl, James Stevens, ''Encyclopaedia of Architectural Terms'', 1993, Donhead Publishing, London</ref> Where the faces rise to a single point, this is often known by terms using "diamond", and is covered below. They may also, usually in blocks that are oblong rather than square, rise to a ridge in the centre. Both types are illustrated, with several others, by Serlio.<ref>Summerson, fig. 52</ref>
<gallery widths="200px" heights="200px"> File:Bugnato casa di Giulio Romano Mantova.JPG|"V" joints and roughened faces within a flat margin, [[Giulio Romano]] for his house in [[Mantua]] File:Boulevard Saint-Germain, 286 (vermiculure).jpg|Vermiculation at 286 [[Boulevard Saint-Germain]], Paris File:3428MantovaPescherie.jpg|An unusual pattern book of effects in the Loggia di [[Giulio Romano]] in [[Mantua]] File:Diana Fountain in Bushy Park 3 (cropped).jpg|"Frost-work" on the [[Diana Fountain, Bushy Park|Diana Fountain]], London, c. 1690 File:Scotland Yard plaque.jpg|Smooth-faced rustication with the blocks dropping back to the wall at 90°, rather than a "V" [[chamfer]] File:2010-06-12 Přestavba nádraží v Telči - (19).JPG|[[Quoin]]s only, with long and short strips, on a Czech railway station File:Howard M. Metzenbaum United States Courthouse - DSC07907.JPG|Banded, with "elbows" and very wide joints, [[Cleveland, Ohio]] File:Liberal Arts Building (3298746194).jpg|Banded rustication in a wholly modern context, [[Hattiesburg, Mississippi]]
</gallery>
===Diamond rustication=== [[Image:Catane Université.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Sicilian Baroque]] [[pilaster]]s with two types of prismatic rustication against a smooth background at the [[University of Catania]]]] Various types of other patterns in masonry surfaces are sometimes called rustication. These include "diamond point" or "diamond rustication" where the face of each stone is a low [[pyramid]] facing out.<ref>Woodman</ref> This covered the whole facade of the [[Palazzo dei Diamanti]] in [[Ferrara]], completed in 1503, and most of that of the [[Palace of Facets]] in the [[Moscow Kremlin]], designed by Italians and completed in 1492, with rectangular "diamonds". These "diamond palaces" influenced other whole walls of diamonds at [[Casa dos Bicos]] in Portugal (after 1523, alternate stones only), and [[Crichton Castle]] in Scotland (c. 1585; all stones, with flat edges between pyramids).
The round towers at the [[Castello Sforzesco]] in [[Milan]] almost use diamonds, but their points are smoothed over. The illustration at right, from [[Catania]] in Sicily, alternates rows of three square "diamond" blocks with two oblong blocks, where the faces rise to a ridge rather than a point, showing both the main forms of "prismatic rustication".
The sharply pointed styles have really nothing to do with classical rustication, and are instead a development of styles of raised decoration of masonry that were popular in late [[Gothic architecture]], especially the Iberian [[Manueline]] (or Portuguese late Gothic) and its equivalent in Spain, known as [[Isabelline Gothic]]. When not figurative these are known as [[bossage]]. These are probably a development of [[Mudéjar]] styles of patterning walls. In the spectacular late 15th-century gateway to the [[Palacio de Jabalquinto]] in [[Baeza]], [[Andalucia]], small widely spaced pyramids cover one of the many zones with fancy carved elements, projecting from a wall otherwise in ashlar.
Later, in [[Baroque architecture]], relatively small areas of diamond rustication were reintegrated into architecture in the classical tradition, and were popular as highlights, especially in [[Sicily]] and southern Italy and Eastern and [[Central Europe]]. The large [[Černín Palace]] in [[Prague]] (1660s) repeats the Kremlin formula of a broad zone of diamonds across the middle height of the facade, though like the towers in Milan these do not come to a point.<ref>Woodman</ref>
<gallery widths="200px" heights="200px" perrow="4"> File:Fachada Palacio Jabalquinto Baeza.jpg|Late 15th-century gateway to the [[Palacio de Jabalquinto]], with small "diamonds" erupting from [[ashlar]] at the sides File:Ferrara 07-05 (67).jpg|[[Palazzo dei Diamanti]], [[Ferrara]] File:Casa dos Bicos - Lisboa.jpg|[[Casa dos Bicos]], [[Lisbon]] File:Wernberg Kloster Nordportal Wappen Ehefrau Anna 14112014 915.jpg|"Diamond rustication" in Germany </gallery>
==Feigned rustication== [[File:MountVernon-Rustication.JPG|thumb|Simple smooth-faced rustication in wood at [[Mount Vernon]]; an imitation of European style popular in America]] The appearance of rustication, creating a rough, unfinished stone-like surface, can be worked on a wooden exterior. This process became popular in 18th century New England to translate the features of [[Palladian architecture]] to the house-carpenter's idiom: in Virginia [[Monticello]] and [[Mount Vernon (plantation)|Mount Vernon]] both made use of this technique. Mount Vernon in particular makes extensive use of feigned rustication and sanded paint and the original finished surfaces of several original planks still survive.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mountvernon.org/visit/plan/index.cfm/pid/541/ |title=George Washington's Mount Vernon - Rustication |accessdate=2008-08-03 |work=Mount Vernon |publisher=Mount Vernon Ladies' Association |year=2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081229065757/http://www.mountvernon.org/visit/plan/index.cfm/pid/541/ |archivedate=2008-12-29 |df= }}</ref>
Rustication of a wooden exterior consists of three basic steps. First, the wood is cut, sanded and prepared with [[bevel]]ed grooves that make each plank appear as if it were a series of stone blocks. Second, the wood is painted with a thick coat of paint. Third, while the paint is still wet, sand is thrown or air blasted onto the planks until no more sand will stick. After the paint dries the plank is ready for use.
In [[Central Europe]], especially the [[Czech Republic]], feigned rustication in [[sgraffito]] (decoration by scraping away one colour of coating on an exterior to show another beneath) is a feature from the Late Renaissance onwards, continuing into the 20th century. Often "prismatic" or "diamond" rustication is imitated.
== See also == * [[Rusticated concrete block]]
==Notes== {{reflist|30em}}
==References== {{Commons category}} *[[Robert Chitham|Chitham, Robert]], ''The Classical Orders Of Architecture'', 2005 rev edn., Elsevier/Architectural Press. {{ISBN|9780750661249}}, [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=WuZdBgAAQBAJ&pg=PA126 google books] *McKay, William Barr, ''McKay's Building Construction'', 2015 (reprint), Routledge, {{ISBN|1317341090}}, 9781317341093, [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=VO8vCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA38 google books] *[[John Summerson|Summerson, John]], ''[[The Classical Language of Architecture]]'', 1980 edition, [[Thames and Hudson]] ''World of Art'' series, {{ISBN|0500201773}} *Woodman = Francis Woodman and Jacques Heyman, "Masonry, ii) Rustication ''and'' Vermiculation", Grove Art Online, [[Oxford Art Online]], Oxford University Press, accessed 2 Apr. 2016, [http://www.oxfordartonline.com/subscriber/article/grove/art/T054954 subscription required]
{{Stonemasonry}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Rustication (Architecture)}} [[Category:Stonemasonry]] [[Category:Architectural styles]] [[Category:Building stone]] [[Category:Architectural elements]] [[Category:Architectural history]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Sukhinder Singh Cassidy | image = Sukhinder_Singh_Cassidy.jpg | image_size = 220px | alt = Headshot of Sukhinder Singh Cassidy | caption = Sukhinder Singh Cassidy at Joyus | birth_date = 1970 | birth_name = Sukhinder Singh | birth_place = [[Dar es Salaam]], Tanzania | occupation = President, [[StubHub]] | spouse = Simon Cassidy | children = 3 | residence = [[Atherton, California]] | alma_mater = [[University of Western Ontario]], [[Richard Ivey School of Business]] | website = {{URL|joyus.com}} | boards = [[TripAdvisor]], J. Hilburn, [[Ericsson]] }}
'''Sukhinder Singh Cassidy''' (born '''Sukhinder Singh''' in 1970) is a technology executive and entrepreneur. She has worked at companies including [[Google]], [[Amazon.com|Amazon]] and [[News Corp]], [[Yodlee]] (YODL), and [[Polyvore]].<ref name="SSC Bio">{{cite web|title=theBoardlist Team|url=https://theboardlist.com/press-resources|website=theBoardlist}}</ref> In 2011, she founded JOYUS, the video shopping platform for women, and served as CEO then Chairman until 2017.<ref>{{cite web|title=Joyus Launches V-Commerce|url=http://www.wwd.com/media-news/digital/joyus-launches-v-commerce-5201360|website=Women's Wear Daily}}</ref> Singh Cassidy is also Founder of theBoardlist.<ref name="fortune.com">{{cite web|title=Joyus' CEO has a new plan to get more women onto startup boards|url=http://fortune.com/2015/07/15/joyus-ceo-diversity-board/|website=Fortune}}</ref>
==Early life and education== Sukhinder Cassidy was born in 1970 in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania to parents of [[Sikhism|Sikh]] descent. Her family moved to Ontario, Canada, when she was two years old. She grew up in [[St. Catharines]], in Canada's Niagara Region.<ref name="bizjournal">{{cite web|title=Sukhinder Singh Cassidy: CEO of Polyvore's ‘appetite for change’ creates Silicon Valley success|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/sanjose/stories/2010/03/22/focus4.html?page=all|website=Silicon Valley Business Journal}}</ref> Sukhinder Cassidy graduated from the [[University of Western Ontario]] and earned her H.B.A. from the [[Richard Ivey School of Business]] in 1992.
Sukhinder Cassidy was raised in an entrepreneurial family. Both of her parents were doctors and ran a medical practice for thirty years.<ref name="Inner Entrepreneur">{{cite web|title=Ex-Google exec Singh Cassidy on Joyus and facing her "inner entrepreneur"|url=http://fortune.com/2011/08/01/ex-google-exec-singh-cassidy-on-joyus-and-facing-her-inner-entrepreneur/|website=Fortune}}</ref>
==Career==
===Early career=== Sukhinder Cassidy started her career in investment banking at [[Merrill Lynch]] in New York. She moved to the Merrill Lynch London office 1994. She then worked as an analyst for British Sky Broadcasting.<ref name="Dealmaker Bloomberg">{{cite web|title=The Rise of a Dealmaker|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2001-02-26/the-rise-of-a-dealmaker|website=Bloomberg|publisher=Bloomberg}}</ref>
In 1998, Sukhinder Cassidy moved to Silicon Valley and joined ecommerce startup [[Junglee (company)]] as Head of Business Development. Junglee was acquired by [[Amazon.com|Amazon]] in 1998.<ref>{{cite web|title=Amazon to Buy two Companies|url=http://news.cnet.com/Amazon-to-buy-two-companies/2100-1001_3-214057.html|publisher=CNET}}</ref> Following the acquisition, Sukhinder Cassidy joined Amazon, where she led merchant business development for the first generation of Amazon marketplace. According to Bloomberg Business, she helped create "one of the company's first programs designed to deliver shoppers to merchants that carried what the buyers were looking for."<ref name="Dealmaker Bloomberg" />
Sukhinder Cassidy co-founded financial services platform [[Yodlee]] in 1999 with five engineering co-founders, including Schwark Satyavolu.<ref name="Dealmaker Bloomberg" /> and served as SVP of Sales and Business Development from 1999 to 2003. In 2014, Yodlee went public, trading under the ticker YODL.<ref>{{cite web|title=Yodlee, a Hub for Financial Apps, Raises $75 Million in I.P.O.|url=https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2014/10/02/yodlee-a-hub-for-financial-apps-raises-75-million-in-i-p-o/|website=DealBook|publisher=New York Times}}</ref>
In 2003, Sukhinder Cassidy joined Google as the first General Manager for Google Local & Maps, and Head of Content Acquisition for Books, Library, Scholar, Shopping and Video. There she launched Google Local and Maps, with product manager [[Bret Taylor]] and a team of engineers. In 2004, she became head of Google's international operations in Asia Pacific (APAC) and Latin America (LATAM), becoming VP in 2005 and then President of APAC and LATAM in 2008. Singh-Cassidy is credited with building Google's presence across 103 countries in Asia Pacific and Latin America.<ref>{{cite web|title=Yet another Googler leaves: Singh Cassidy joins Accel Partners|url=https://venturebeat.com/2009/04/07/yet-another-googler-leaves-singh-cassidy-joins-accel-partners/|website=VentureBeat}}</ref>
In 2009, Sukhinder Cassidy left Google to become CEO-in-Residence at venture capital firm [[Accel Partners]].<ref name="Accel Release">{{cite web|title=Accel Partners Adds Google Executive Sukhinder Singh Cassidy as CEO-in-Residence|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/accel-partners-adds-google-executive-sukhinder-singh-cassidy-as-ceo-in-residence-61770492.html}}</ref> Singh Cassidy was named CEO of [[Polyvore]] in 2010,.<ref>{{cite web|title=Former Google Exec Singh Cassidy Becomes CEO of Fashion Start-up Polyvore|url=http://allthingsd.com/20100222/former-google-exec-singh-cassidy-becomes-ceo-of-fashion-start-up-polyvore/|website=All Things D|publisher=Dow Jones & Co.}}</ref>
===Joyus=== In October 2010, Sukhinder Cassidy had the idea for a new platform aimed at converging content and commerce through online video as a way to increase consumer engagement with products and drive direct purchases via the video.<ref name="Economic Times">{{cite web|title=Ex-Google honcho Sukhinder Singh Cassidy sets up video shopping online network Joyus|url=http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2013-04-07/news/38346401_1_google-accel-partners-sukhinder-singh-cassidy|website=The Economic Times}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Making Shopping Social With Video: Joyus Founder Sukhinder Singh-Cassidy|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/meghancasserly/2011/11/08/making-shopping-social-with-video-joyus-founder-sukhinder-singh-cassidy/|website=Forbes}}</ref> She founded JOYUS in January, 2011 in San Francisco, CA. Joyus.com launched to the public in August, 2011.<ref name="Inner Entrepreneur"/> Singh Cassidy raised $7.9 million in seed funding from Accel Partners, Harrison Metal, Joel Hyatt, Venky Harinarayan & Anand Rajaraman.<ref name="Joyus funding">{{cite web|title=Premium Video Commerce Site Joyus — Headed by Top Ex-Googler — Gets $7.9 Million in Funding|url=http://allthingsd.com/20110801/premium-video-commerce-site-joyus-headed-by-top-ex-googler-gets-7-9-million-in-funding/|website=All Things D}}</ref> In 2012, JOYUS raised a second round of funding totaling $11.5 million from Interwest and Time Warner, as well as existing investors.<ref name="Joyus second funding">{{cite web|title=Video Shopping Startup Joyus Raises $11.5 million in Second Round, Focuses on ROI of Online Retail|url=http://allthingsd.com/20130505/video-shopping-startup-joyus-raises-11-5m-in-second-round-focuses-on-roi-of-online-retail/|website=All Things D}}</ref>
JOYUS was ranked one of the "Hot 100" e-retailing websites by Internet Retailer in 2012;<ref>{{cite web|title=2013 Hot 100|url=https://www.internetretailer.com/2012/11/27/shopping-video|website=Internet Retailer}}</ref> and one of the "Top 25 Ecommerce Companies to Watch" by Brand Innovators in 2013.<ref name="brandinnovators">{{cite web|title=Brand Innovators Honors West Coast With "Top 25 E-Commerce Companies to Watch" List|url=http://brand-innovators.com/blog/2013/05/08/brand-innovators-honors-west-coast-with-top-25-e-commerce-companies-to-watch-list/|website=Brand-Innovators.com}}</ref> JOYUS was a winner of the 2013 Brightcove Innovation Awards<ref>{{cite web|title=a winner of the 2013 Brightcove Innovation Awards|url=https://www.brightcove.com/en/company/press/2013-brightcove-innovation-award-winners-announced-play-2013-global-customer-conference|website=Brightcove}}</ref> and a winner of the 2013 L’Oreal Next Generation Digital Awards.<ref name="L'Oreal">{{cite web|title=Women in Digital: Class of 2013|url=http://lorealwomenindigital.com/awards/class-2013|website=L'Oreal Women in Digital|publisher=L'Oreal}}</ref> JOYUS was featured by [[Apple Inc.|Apple]] as one of the best Lifestyle shopping apps for the 2014 holiday season.
JOYUS was acquired by StackCommerce in September, 2017.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://techcrunch.com/2017/09/29/stackcommerce-buys-joyus-to-focus-on-video-and-expand-into-fashion-shopping-and-beauty/|title=StackCommerce buys Joyus to focus on video and expand into fashion, shopping and beauty|last=Shieber|first=Jonathan|work=TechCrunch|access-date=2017-10-08|language=en}}</ref>
===#ChoosePossibility Project and theBoardlist=== In May 2015, Sukhinder Cassidy published an open letter, titled "Tech Women Choose Possibility", challenging the tech community to increase the rate of progress for women in the industry by leveraging its wealth of existing female talent.<ref>{{cite web|title=Tech Women Choose Possibility|url=http://recode.net/2015/05/13/tech-women-choose-possibility/|website=Re/Code}}</ref> The letter was co-signed by 59 female entrepreneurs and investors. Singh Cassidy based the letter on her own experiences as a tech entrepreneur and research she conducted on 230 female founders and CEOs of tech companies.<ref>{{cite web|title=#ChoosePossibility Project|url=https://medium.com/@sukhindersinghcassidy/choosepossibility-project-90a217ff0a86#.gsuea6pjx|website=Medium}}</ref>
Sukhinder Cassidy launched [[theBoardlist]], the first initiative of the #ChoosePossibility Project, on July 15, 2015.<ref name="fortune.com"/> theBoardlist is an online marketplace that connects CEOs who are looking for board candidates with women who are peer-endorsed for private and public tech company boards. When it launched, theBoardlist included the names of over 600 women who had been endorsed by 50 investors and CEOs in the tech industry, from companies including [[Accel Partners]], [[Greylock Partners]], [[Twitter]], [[Lyft]] and Box.<ref>{{cite web|title=A Woman On Every Startup Board? Why Not, Says Ex-Google Exec|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/ellenhuet/2015/07/15/a-woman-on-every-startup-board-boardlist-sukhinder-singh-cassidy/|website=Forbes}}</ref>
On October 20, 2015, theBoardlist announced that it had facilitated its first placement of a woman to the board of a private tech company.<ref>{{cite web|title=Boardlist, The Tool For Getting Women On Tech Boards, Has Its First Win|url=https://techcrunch.com/2015/10/20/boardlist-the-tool-for-getting-women-on-tech-boards-has-its-first-win/|website=TechCrunch}}</ref>
As of late 2017, theBoardlist had attracted over 1,400 executives to nominate over 2,100 women for board service, and influenced over 100 board placements.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Boss: Sukhinder Singh Cassidy Is on a Mission to Get More Women on Company Boards|url=http://motto.time.com/5022322/sukhinder-singh-cassidy-sexism-tech/|website=Motto|publisher=Time, Inc.}}</ref>
In April 2018, Singh Cassidy was named the president of [[StubHub]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Sukhinder Singh Cassidy Named President of StubHub|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/business/8290113/stubhub-sukhinder-singh-cassidy-named-president|website=Billboard|publisher=Billboard}}</ref>
==Personal life== Sukhinder Cassidy is married to Simon Cassidy, a fellow Canadian and former hedge-fund manager who runs an independent investment firm.<ref name="Inner Entrepreneur" /> The couple has three children and lives in the San Francisco Bay area.
==Organizations founded== * Yodlee<ref name="Dealmaker Bloomberg" /> * Joyus<ref name="Economic Times" /> * theBoardlist<ref name="fortune.com"/>
==Board member and advisor== Sukhinder Cassidy serves as a public board director at [[TripAdvisor]] (TRIP),<ref>{{cite web|title=Board of Directors|url=http://ir.tripadvisor.com/corporate-governance/board-of-directors|website=TripAdvisor|publisher=TripAdvisor, LLC}}</ref> [[Ericsson]] (ERIC),<ref>{{cite web|title=Board of Directors|url=http://www.ericsson.com/thecompany/corporate_governance/board_of_directors/members_of_the_board|website=Ericcson}}</ref> and [[Urban Outfitters]] (URBN).<ref>{{cite web|title=URBN Appoints a New Member to the Board of Directors|url=http://investor.urbn.com/news-releases/news-release-details/urbn-appoints-new-member-board-directors-and-announces|website=Urban Outfitters|publisher=Urban Outfitters, Inc.}}</ref> She previously served on the boards of [[J. Crew]] Group, Inc.(JCG), StitchFix, and as an advisor to [[Twitter]].<ref name="SSC Bio" />
==Honors== * Named one of the Most Creative People in Business by Fast Company (2017)<ref>{{cite web|title=The Most Creative People in Business|url=https://www.fastcompany.com/most-creative-people-community/c/1|website=Fast Company|publisher=Mansueto Ventures, LLC}}</ref> * Named one of the "Silicon Valley 100" by Business Insider (2016, 2012)<ref>{{cite web|title=Silicon Valley 100|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/silicon-valley-100-2016-6/#75-sukhinder-singh-cassidy-26|website=Business Insider|publisher=Business Insider Inc.}}</ref> * Named a "Power Women" by Forbes (2014)<ref name="Forbes Power Women">{{cite web|title=The Power Women Who Are Reinventing The Way You Shop Fashion Online|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/carolinehoward/2014/05/28/the-power-women-who-are-reinventing-the-way-you-shop-online/|website=Forbes}}</ref> * Featured in book, ''Good Leaders Learn: Lessons from Lifetimes of Leadership'' (2013)<ref>{{cite book|last1=Seijts|first1=Gerard|title=Good Leaders Learn : Lessons from Lifetimes of Leadership|date=2013|publisher=Routledge|location=London|isbn=978-0415659772|pages=186–195}}</ref> * Named one of "The Silicon Valley 100" by Business Insider (2012)<ref name="Business Insider 100">{{cite web|title=The Silicon Valley 100|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/the-silicon-valley-100-2012-1#93-sukhinder-si|website=Business Insider}}</ref> * Named one of "44 Female Founders Every Entrepreneur Should Know" (2012)<ref>{{cite web|title=44 Female Founders Every Entrepreneur Should Know|url=http://mashable.com/2012/08/06/female-founders/|website=Mashable}}</ref> * Named one of "14 Incredible Women to Watch in Silicon Valley" (2012)<ref>{{cite web|title=14 Incredible Women to Watch in Silicon Valley|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/14-incredible-women-to-watch-in-silicon-valley-2012-2?op=1|website=Business Insider}}</ref> * Included in Ad Age list of "Women to Watch" (2010)<ref name="Ad Age">{{cite web|title=Women to Watch: Sukhinder Singh Cassidy|url=http://adage.com/article/special-report-women-to-watch-2010/women-watch-2010-sukhinder-singh-cassidy/144240/|website=Ad Age}}</ref> * Selected as TechFellow Awards’ first General Management Fellow in recognition of outstanding innovation in General Management (2009)<ref>{{cite web|title=Sukhinder Singh|url=http://www.techfellows.com/general-management/2009/sukhinder-singh-cassidy/|website=TechFellow Awards}}</ref> * Named by Fortune as one of "tech's next-gen leaders" and featured on the cover of the annual ''Most Powerful Women'' Magazine addition (2008)<ref>{{cite web|title=My tech 'a-ha' moment: Sukhinder Singh Cassidy|url=http://archive.fortune.com/galleries/2008/fortune/0809/gallery.mpw_valleygirls_qs.fortune/8.html|website=Fortune}}</ref>
==Notable Speaker== * Keynote Speaker, Dreamforce 2016<ref>{{cite web|title=Dreamforce Keynotes|url=https://www.salesforce.com/dreamforce/DF16/keynotes-cassidy/|website=Dreamforce|publisher=Salesforce.com, Inc.}}</ref> * Keynote Speaker, Retail Council of Canada, Store 2015<ref>{{cite web|title=Sukhinder Singh Cassidy|url=http://www.storeconference.ca/speakers/sukhinder-singh|website=Store Conference|publisher=Retail Council of Canada}}</ref> * Keynote Speaker at IRCE 2014 – Internet Retailer Conference & Exhibition<ref>{{cite web|title=Sukhinder Singh Cassidy, Chairman and Founder, Joyus|url=http://www.marketingsherpa.com/irce/videos/sukhinder-cassidy.php|website=Marketing Sherpa}}</ref> * Keynote Speaker, D2C Convention 2014<ref>{{cite web|title=Sukhinder Singh Cassidy Named Keynote Speaker for 2014 ERA D2C Convention|url=http://www.marketwired.com/press-release/sukhinder-singh-cassidy-named-keynote-speaker-for-2014-era-d2c-convention-1927433.htm|website=Market Wired|publisher=Marketwire}}</ref> * Keynote Speaker, Stanford University's Entrepreneurship Thought Leadership Series, 2012<ref>{{cite web|title=Find Your Vector of Impact|url=http://ecorner.stanford.edu/authorMaterialInfo.html?mid=2896|website=Stanford University Entrepreneurship Corner}}</ref> * Keynote Speaker, SVB CEO Summit West, 2012<ref>{{cite web|title=How to Scale Yourself as CEO|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ImCeG2Z3688|website=Youtube}}</ref> * Speaker, AllThingsD Asia, 2011<ref>{{cite web|title=SurveyMonkey's Dave Goldberg, Joyus's Sukhinder Singh Cassidy and Airbnb's Brian Chesky: Highlights From AsiaD|url=http://allthingsd.com/20111020/surveymonkey%E2%80%99s-dave-goldberg-joyus%E2%80%99-sukhinder-singh-cassidy-and-airbnb%E2%80%99s-brian-chesky-video-highlights-from-asiad-video/|website=All Things D}}</ref> * Keynote speaker at DLDWomen, 2010<ref>{{cite web|title=Sukhinder Singh Cassidy|url=http://dld-conference.com/users/sukhiner-singh-cassidy|website=DLD (Digital-Life-Design)}}</ref> * Keynote Speaker at India Conclave, 2007<ref>{{cite web|title=Consumers will run the show|url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/thornton-may-on-web-media-being-free-in-india-today-2007/1/155902.html|website=India Today}}</ref> * Featured in book, ''Innovation nation : Canadian leadership from Java to Jurassic Park'' (2002)<ref>{{cite book|last1=Brody|first1=Leonard|title=Innovation nation : Canadian leadership from Java to Jurassic Park|date=2002|publisher=Wiley|location=Etobicoke, Ont.|isbn=978-0-470-83202-8|pages=185–190}}</ref>
==Angel Investor== Singh Cassidy is a select angel investor whose investments include: * Stitch Fix<ref>{{cite web|title=Stitch Fix: Reinventing Retail Through Personalization|url=http://abovethecrowd.com/2013/10/17/stitch-fix-reinventing-retail-through-personalization/|website=Above the Crowd|publisher=Bill Gurley}}</ref> * the Real Real<ref>{{cite web|title=The RealReal Raises $14 Million in Series B to Expand Its Lead in Reselling Authenticated Luxury Designer Goods|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/the-realreal-raises-14-million-in-series-b-to-expand-its-lead-in-reselling-authenticated-luxury-designer-goods-203206341.html|website=PR Newswire}}</ref> * Soma Water<ref>{{cite web|title=Charitable Water Filter Maker Soma Raises $3.7M Seed Round|url=https://techcrunch.com/2013/07/16/charitable-water-filter-maker-soma-raises-3-7m-seed-round/|website=TechCrunch}}</ref> * J. Hilburn<ref>{{cite web|title=J.Hilburn Rapidly Building the Next Great Men's Retail Brand|url=https://finance.yahoo.com/news/j-hilburn-rapidly-building-next-130000313.html|website=Yahoo Finance|publisher=Yahoo}}</ref> * Heartwork
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [https://twitter.com/sukhindersingh/ Sukhinder on Twitter] * [https://www.theboardlist.com/ theBoardlist] * [https://twitter.com/theboardlist/ theBoardlist on Twitter]

revision.comment: Precisions on TSO usage for aircraft installation
revision.text:
A '''Technical Standard Order''' ('''TSO''') is a minimum performance standard issued by the [[United States]] [[Federal Aviation Administration]] for specified materials, parts, processes, and appliances used on [[civil aircraft]]. Articles with TSO design approval are eligible for use on the United States [[Type certification|type certified]] products by following a much lighter process than similar non-TSO approved part, provided the TSO standard meets the aircraft requirements<ref>https://www.aea.net/events/rotorcraft/files/Aug2013/FAA_InstallofTSOd.pdf</ref>. The TSO authorization (also called '''TSOA''') or a letter of TSO Design Approval does not necessarily convey approval for installation. See 14 CFR Part 21 Subpart O<ref>https://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/CFR-2011-title14-vol1/pdf/CFR-2011-title14-vol1-part21-subpartO.pdf</ref>.
Similar standards are maintained by other aviation authorities (for example [[European Technical Standard Order|ETSO]][https://www.easa.europa.eu/easa-and-you/aircraft-products/etso-authorisations] by [[EASA]] for [[European Union]]), with limited reciprocal equivalence on a per-country basis <ref>https://www.easa.europa.eu/system/files/dfu/TSOA-ETSOA-Reciprocal-Acceptance-FAQs.pdf</ref>
==See also== *[[Type certificate]] *[[Supplemental type certificate]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.airweb.faa.gov/Regulatory_and_Guidance_Library/rgTSO.nsf/MainFrame?OpenFrameSet FAA page on Technical Standard Orders] **[http://concordebattery.com/batterytsoexplained.php What is TSO? TSO FAQ.]
[[Category:Avionics]] [[Category:Aviation licenses and certifications]] [[Category:Federal Aviation Administration]]
{{aviation-stub}}

revision.comment: /* Industrial use */ Removed an entry regarding unsuitability for use as a fuel line on a specific model of motorcycle, with reference to an online hobbyist forum.
revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=April 2008}} [[File:Tygon logo.svg|thumb|Tygon logo]] '''Tygon''' is a brand name for a ''family'' of flexible polymer tubing consisting of a ''variety'' of materials to be used "across a range of specialized fluid transfer requirements".<ref>http://www.processsystems.saint-gobain.com/brand-transition.aspx</ref> The specific composition of each type is a trade secret. Some variants have multiple layers of different materials. Tygon is a registered trademark of [[Saint-Gobain]] Corporation. It is an invented word, owned and used by Saint-Gobain and originated in the late 1930s. Tygon products are produced in three countries, but sold throughout the world. Tygon tubing is used in many markets, including food and beverage, chemical processing, industrial, laboratory, medical, pharmaceutical, and semiconductor processing. There are many formulations of clear, flexible, Tygon tubing. The chemical resistance and physical properties vary among the different formulations, but the tubing generally is intended to be "so resistant to chemical attack that it will handle practically any chemical", whether liquid, gas, or slurry.<ref>Shugar, Gershon J. and Jack T. Ballinger, ''Chemical technicians' ready reference handbook, fourth edition'', page 378, McGraw-Hill 1996 {{ISBN|0-07-057186-4}}</ref> While largely non-reactive, Tygon has been reported to liberate [[carbon monoxide]] and is listed among [[carbon monoxide-releasing molecules]].
==Formulations and applications==
===Food and beverage applications=== ''Tygon B-44-3'', ''Tygon B-44-4X'', ''Tygon B-44-4X I.B.,'' and ''Tygon Silver'' (antimicrobial) were widely used in the food and beverage industry, in particular in: beverage dispensing, dairy processing, soft-serve dispensing, vitamin and flavor concentrate systems, cosmetic production, and water purification systems. These formulations each meet U.S. [[Food and Drug Administration]] 3-A and [[NSF International]] 51 criteria but they do not comply with European Directives (European Directive 2002/72/EC of 6 August 2002 relating to plastic materials and articles intended to come into contact with foodstuffs as modified in particular by Directive 2007/19/EC of 2 April 2007).
=== Class VI approved === Several formulations of Tygon are [[United States Pharmacopeia|USP]] class VI approved and can be used in either surgical procedures or pharmaceutical processing.
====Medical==== ''Tygon Medical/Surgical Tubing S-50-HL'' — Characterized to the latest [[ISO 10993]] standards and U.S. [[Food and Drug Administration]] (FDA) guidelines for [[biocompatibility]]. This material is non-toxic, non-[[hemolysis|hemolytic]], and non-[[Pyrogen (fever)|pyrogenic]]. This formulation is used in minimally invasive devices, [[dialysis]] equipment, for [[bypass procedure]]s, and [[chemotherapy]] drug delivery.
''Tygon Medical Tubing S-54-HL'' was introduced in 1964 for use in medical applications. This material can be used in [[catheter]]s, for intravenous or intra-arterial infusion and other surgical uses. Tygon S-54-HL can also be fabricated into [[cannula]]e or protective sheath products using [[thermoforming]] and flaring techniques.
====Pharmaceutical==== ''Tygon LFL'' (Long Flex Life) pump tubing is non-toxic clear tubing with broad chemical resistance.{{Citation needed|date=June 2008}} It is often used in product filtration and fermentation and [[surfactant]] delivery.
''Tygon 2275 High Purity Tubing'' is a plasticizer-free material that is often used in sterile filling and dispensing systems and diagnostic equipment. This formulation is also considered to have low [[absorption (chemistry)|absorption]]/[[adsorption]] properties, which minimizes the risk of fluid alteration.
''Tygon 2275 I.B. High-Purity Pressure Tubing'' is plasticizer-free and is reinforced with a braid for use with elevated working pressures.
===Peristaltic pumps=== Many formulations of Tygon can be used in [[peristaltic pump]]s, including the following:
''Tygon R-3603 Laboratory Tubing'' is commonly used in chemical laboratories. It is often used in incubators and as a replacement for rubber tubing for [[Bunsen burner]]s. This material is produced in vacuum sizes and can withstand a full vacuum at room temperature.
''Tygon R-1000 Ultra-Soft Tubing'' is used in general laboratory applications. It is the softest of the Tygon formulations with a [[Shore durometer|durometer]] hardness of Shore A 40 (ASTM Method D2240-02). Because of the low [[durometer]] of this material it is often used in low-[[torque]] peristaltic pumps.
''Tygon LFL'' (Long Flex Life) Pump Tubing, ''Tygon 3350'', ''Tygon S-50-HL Medical/Surgical'' Tubing, ''Tygon 2275 High Purity Tubing'', and ''Tygon 2001'' Tubing are also used in peristaltic pump applications.
=== Plasticizer-free/non-DEHP === Tygon tubing is available in Plasticizer-free/non-[[DEHP]] (non-[[Phthalate]])-formulations. These formulations have a high degree of chemical resistance and do not release any hazardous material when properly incinerated. ''Tygon 2275 High Purity tubing'', ''Tygon Ultra Chemical Resistant Tubing 2075'', and ''Tygon Plasticizer Free Tubing 2001'' are all [[plasticizer]]-free. "ND-100 series" products are non-DEHP and use a non-Phthalate plasticizer.
''Tygon Silver'' Tubing has a plasticizer-free inner bore and a [[silver]]-based compound on the inner surface to decrease bacterial growth and protect against [[microbes]].
===Industrial use=== There are several formulations of Tygon that are used in industrial applications.
* ''Tygon Fuel and Lubricant Tubing F-4040-A'' is translucent yellow for positive identification and flow monitoring. It is used in small engine fuel lines, [[recreational vehicle]]s, and lubrication lines. * ''Tygon LP1100'' is a low permeation [[Environmental Protection Agency|EPA]] and [[California Air Resources Board|CARB]] certified fuel line<ref>http://www.processsystems.saint-gobain.com/tygon-lp1100-tubing.aspx</ref> also used in small engines. * ''Tygon R-3400 UV Resistant Tubing'' is black in color and opaque. It remains flexible in [[ultraviolet]] (UV) environments and is often used for electrical insulation, ink, and adhesive dispensing, and fertilizer and pesticide dispensing. Because it is resistant to UV light, [[ozone]], and weathering, it is commonly used in outdoor applications. * ''Tygon 2075 Ultra Chemical Resistant Tubing'' is a plasticizer-free material that is known for its high degree of chemical resistance. It can be used in ink and printing fluid dispensing, paint and solvent production, and is resistant to [[Butanone|MEK]] and other chemicals. When properly incinerated it releases only [[carbon dioxide]] and water. * ''Tygon 2375 Ultra Chemical Resistant Tubing'' is now replacing Tygon 2075.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.tygon.com/ Saint-Gobain Web site] *[http://www.flaredpumptubing.com/ Flared tubing Web site]
[[Category:Industrial equipment]] [[Category:Saint-Gobain]]

revision.comment: Bender235 moved page [[Uzawa's Theorem]] to [[Uzawa's theorem]]: per naming convention
revision.text:
'''Uzawa's theorem''', also known as the '''steady state growth theorem''', is a theorem in [[Economic growth|economic growth theory]] concerning the form that [[technological change]] can take in the [[Solow–Swan model|Solow–Swan]] and [[Ramsey–Cass–Koopmans model|Ramsey–Cass–Koopmans]] growth models. It was first proved by Japanese economist [[Hirofumi Uzawa]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Uzawa|first=Hirofumi|date=Summer 1961|title=Neutral Inventions and the Stability of Growth Equilibrium|url=|journal=The Review of Economic Studies|volume=28|pages=117-124|via=}}</ref>
One general version of the theorem consists of two parts.<ref name="Jones & Scrimgeour">{{cite journal |first=Charles I. |last=Jones |first2=Dean |last2=Scrimgeour |year=2008 |title=A New Proof of Uzawa's Steady-State Growth Theorem |journal=[[Review of Economics and Statistics]] |volume=90 |issue=1 |pages=180–182 |doi=10.1162/rest.90.1.180 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title=Introduction to Modern Economic Growth|last=Acemoglu|first=Daron|publisher=Princeton University Press|year=2009|isbn=978-0-691-13292-1|location=Princeton, New Jersey|pages=60-61}}</ref> The first states that, under the normal assumptions of the Solow and Neoclassical models, if (after some time T) capital, investment, consumption, and output are increasing at constant exponential rates, these rates must be equivalent. Building on this result, the second part asserts that, within such a balanced growth path, the production function, <math>Y = \tilde{F}(\tilde{A},K,L)</math> (where <math>A</math> is technology, <math>K</math> is capital, and <math>L</math> is labor), can be rewritten such that technological change affects output solely as a scalar on labor (i.e. <math>Y = F(K,AL)</math>) a property known as [[labor-augmenting]] or [[Harrod neutral|Harrod-neutral]] technological change.
Uzawa's theorem demonstrates a significant limitation of the commonly used Neoclassical and Solow models. Imposing the assumption of balanced growth within such models requires that technological change by labor-augmenting. By contraposition, any production function for which it is not possible to represent the effect of technology as a scalar on labor cannot produce a balanced growth path.<ref name="Jones & Scrimgeour" />
== Statement of Theorem == Throughout this page, a dot over a variable will denote its derivative with respect to time (i.e. <math>\dot{X}(t)\equiv {dX(t) \over dt}</math>). Also, the growth rate of a variable <math>X(t)</math> will be denoted <math>g_X\equiv \frac{\dot{X}(t)}{X(t)}</math>.
'''Uzawa's theorem'''
(The following version is found in Acemoglu (2009) and adapted from Schlicht (2006))
Model with aggregate production function <math>Y(t)=\tilde{F}(\tilde{A}(t),K(t),L(t))</math>, where <math>\tilde{F}:\mathbb{R}^2_+ \times \mathcal{A}\to \mathbb{R}_+</math> and <math>\tilde{A}(t)\in \mathcal{A}</math> represents technology at time t (where <math>\mathcal{A}</math> is an arbitrary subset of <math>\mathbb{R}^N</math> for some natural number <math>N</math>). Assume that <math>\tilde{F}</math> exhibits constant returns to scale in <math>K</math> and <math>L</math>. The growth in capital at time t is given by
<math>\dot{K}(t)=Y(t)-C(t)-\delta K(t)</math>
where <math>\delta </math> is the depreciation rate and <math>C(t)</math> is consumption at time t.
Suppose that population grows at a constant rate, <math>L(t)=\exp(nt)L(0)</math>, and that there exists some time <math>T < \infty</math> such that for all <math>t\geq T</math>, <math>\dot{Y}(t)/Y(t)=g_Y>0</math>, <math>\dot{K}(t)/K(t)=g_K>0</math>, and <math>\dot{C}(t)/C(t)=g_C>0</math>. Then
1. <math>g_Y = g_K = g_C</math>; and
2. For any <math>t \geq T</math> , there exists a function <math>F:\mathbb{R}^2_+ \to \mathbb{R}_+</math> that is homogeneous of degree 1 in its two arguments, such that the aggregate production function can be represented as ''<math>Y(t)=F(K(t),A(t)L(t))</math>'', where <math>A(t)\in \mathbb{R}_+</math> and <math>g \equiv \dot{A}(t)/A(t) =g_Y-n</math>.
== Sketch of proof == ===Lemma 1=== For any constant <math>\alpha</math>, <math>g_{X^\alpha Y}=\alpha g_X+g_Y</math>.
'''Proof''': Observe that for any <math>Z(t)</math>, <math>g_{Z}= \frac{\dot{Z}(t)}{Z(t)}= \frac{d\ln Z(t)}{dt}</math>. Therefore, <math>g_{X^\alpha Y} = \frac{d}{dt}\ln [(X(t))^\alpha Y(t)]=\alpha\frac{d\ln X(t)}{dt}+\frac{d\ln Y(t)}{dt}=\alpha g_X+g_Y</math>.
===Proof of theorem=== We first show that the growth rate of investment <math>I(t)=Y(t)-C(t)</math> must equal the growth rate of capital <math>K(t)</math> (i.e. <math>g_I=g_K</math>)
The resource constraint at time <math>t</math> implies :<math>\dot{K}(t)=I(t)-\delta K(t)</math> By definition of <math>g_K</math>, <math>\dot{K}(t)=g_K K(t)</math> for all <math>t\geq T</math> . Therefore, the previous equation implies :<math>g_K+\delta=\frac{I(t)}{K(t)}</math> for all <math>t\geq T</math>. The left-hand side is a constant, while the right-hand side grows at <math>g_I-g_K</math> (by Lemma 1). Therefore, <math>0=g_I-g_K</math> and thus :<math>g_I=g_K</math>. From [[Gross domestic product#Expenditure approach|national income accounting for a closed economy]], final goods in the economy must either be consumed or invested, thus for all <math>t</math> :<math>Y(t)=C(t)+I(t)</math> Differentiating with respect to time yields :<math>\dot{Y}(t)=\dot{C}(t)+\dot{I}(t)</math> Dividing both sides by <math>Y(t)</math> yields :<math>\frac{\dot{Y}(t)}{Y(t)}=\frac{\dot{C}(t)}{Y(t)}+\frac{\dot{I}(t)}{Y(t)}=\frac{\dot{C}(t)}{C(t)}\frac{C(t)}{Y(t)}+\frac{\dot{I}(t)}{I(t)}\frac{I(t)}{Y(t)}</math> :<math>\Rightarrow g_Y=g_C\frac{C(t)}{Y(t)}+g_I\frac{I(t)}{Y(t)}=g_C\frac{C(t)}{Y(t)}+g_I(1-\frac{C(t)}{Y(t)})=(g_C-g_I)\frac{C(t)}{Y(t)}+g_I</math> Since <math>g_Y, g_C</math> and <math>g_I</math> are constants, <math>\frac{C(t)}{Y(t)}</math> is a constant. Therefore, the growth rate of <math>\frac{C(t)}{Y(t)}</math> is zero. By Lemma 1, it implies that :<math> g_c-g_Y=0</math> Similarly, <math>g_Y= g_I</math>. Therefore, <math>g_Y = g_C = g_K</math>.
Next we show that for any <math>t\geq T</math>, the production function can be represented as one with labor-augmenting technology.
The production function at time <math>T</math> is :<math>Y(T)=\tilde{F}(\tilde{A}(T), K(T), L(T))</math> The constant [[Returns to scale|return to scale]] property of production (<math>\tilde{F}</math> is [[Homogeneous function|homogeneous of degree one]] in <math>K</math> and <math>L</math>) implies that for any <math>t\geq T</math>, multiplying both sides of the previous equation by <math>\frac{Y(t)}{Y(T)}</math> yields :<math>Y(T)\frac{Y(t)}{Y(T)}=\tilde{F}(\tilde{A}(T), K(T)\frac{Y(t)}{Y(T)}, L(T)\frac{Y(t)}{Y(T)})</math> Note that <math>\frac{Y(t)}{Y(T)}=\frac{K(t)}{K(T)}</math> because <math>g_Y=g_K</math>(refer to [[Ordinary differential equation#Summary of exact solutions|solution to differential equations]] for proof of this step). Thus, the above equation can be rewritten as :<math>Y(t)=\tilde{F}(\tilde{A}(T), K(t), L(T)\frac{Y(t)}{Y(T)})</math> For any <math>t\geq T</math>, define :<math>A(t)\equiv\frac{Y(t)}{L(t)}\frac{L(T)}{Y(T)}</math> and :<math>F(K(t),A(t)L(t))\equiv\tilde{F}(\tilde{A}(T), K(t), L(t)A(t))</math> Combining the two equations yields :<math>F(K(t),A(t)L(t))=\tilde{F}(\tilde{A}(T), K(t), L(T)\frac{Y(t)}{Y(T)})=Y(t)</math> for any <math>t\geq T</math>. By construction, <math>F(K,AL)</math> is also [[Homogeneous function|homogeneous of degree one]] in its two arguments.
Moreover, by Lemma 1, the growth rate of <math>A(t)</math> is given by :<math>\frac{\dot{A}(t)}{A(t)}=\frac{\dot{Y}(t)}{Y(t)}-\frac{\dot{L}(t)}{L(t)}=g_Y-n</math>. <math>\blacksquare</math>
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Macroeconomics]] [[Category:Economics theorems]] [[Category:Technological change]]

revision.comment: /* Welfare considerations for rearing */
revision.text:
[[Image:Bamboo worms on plate cropped jpeg.jpg|thumb|right|300px|"[[Omphisa fuscidentalis|Bamboo worms]]" in [[Bangkok]]]]
The '''welfare of farmed insects''' concerns treatment of insects raised for [[animal feed]], [[pet food]], human consumption ([[entomophagy]]), and other purposes like honey and silk.
==Debate over the issue's significance==
Scientists remain uncertain about the existence and degree of [[pain in invertebrates]], including insects. Nonetheless, insect welfare is being taken increasingly seriously in laboratory settings.<ref name=Smith1991>{{cite journal|last=Smith|first=Jane A.|title=A Question of Pain in Invertebrates|journal=ILAR Journal|date=1991|volume=33|issue=1–2|pages=25–31|doi=10.1093/ilar.33.1-2.25}}</ref><ref name="Sherwin, 2001">{{cite journal|author=Sherwin, C.M.|year=2001|title=Can invertebrates suffer? Or, how robust is argument-by-analogy? |journal=Animal Welfare (supplement)|volume=10|pages=103–118}}</ref> Vincent Wigglesworth suggested a precautionary approach of anaesthetizing insects during potentially painful procedures.<ref name=Wigglesworth1980>{{cite journal|last=Wigglesworth|first=Vincent B.|title=Do insects feel pain?|journal=Antenna|date=1980|pages=8–9}}</ref> John Cooper has written about techniques for "[[Anesthesia]], [[analgesia]], and euthanasia of invertebrates" including insects.<ref name=Cooper2011>{{cite journal|last=Cooper|first=John E.|title=Anesthesia, analgesia, and euthanasia of invertebrates|journal=ILAR Journal|date=2011|volume=52|issue=2|pages=196–204|doi=10.1093/ilar.52.2.196}}</ref> Neil A. C. Bennie and colleagues proposed a method for chemical euthanasia of insects and other terrestrial arthropods.<ref name=BennieEtAl2012>{{cite journal|last=Bennie|first=Neil A. C.|author2=Christopher D. Loaring |author3=Mikaella M. G. Bennie |author4=Steven A. Trim |title=An effective method for terrestrial arthropod euthanasia|journal=Journal of Experimental Biology|date=2012|volume=215|pages=4237–4241|doi=10.1242/jeb.074997 |pmid=22996446}}</ref>
Some authors have begun extending discussions of insect welfare beyond the laboratory to the domain of raising insects for food.<ref name=ErensEtAl2012 /><ref name=DeGoedeEtAl2013>{{cite book|last=De Goede|first=D. M.|title=The ethics of consumption: The citizen, the market and the law|date=2013|publisher=Wageningen Academic Publishers|isbn=978-90-8686-784-4|pages=236–242|author2=J. Erens |author3=E. Kapsomenou |author4=M. Peters |editor=Helena Röcklinsberg, Per Sandin|chapter=Large scale insect rearing and animal welfare}}</ref> A new Dutch Animal Act that went into effect on 1 January 2013 creates a regulatory framework for farm-animal welfare based on the [[five freedoms]],<ref name=DeGoedeEtAl2013 /> and the law specifically lists a number of insect species as "production animals" whose wellbeing needs to be respected.<ref name=ErensEtAl2012 /> Dutch politician [[Marianne Thieme]] asked a series of questions suggesting concern that insect farming would multiply the number of animals farmed and killed for human consumption.<ref name=Thieme2012>{{cite web|last1=Thieme|first1=Marianne|title=Questions about insects as a protein source for pig and chicken feed|url=http://www.partijvoordedieren.nl/tweedekamer/kamervragen/2724/i/2747|accessdate=1 June 2014|date=12 Oct 2012}}</ref> Robert Nathan Allen of the pro-entomophagy organization Little Herds feels that the welfare of insects is important, though he believes well managed farms can maintain high standards of care.<ref name=King2014>{{cite web|last=King|first=Barbara J.|title=The Joys And Ethics Of Insect Eating|url=https://www.npr.org/blogs/13.7/2014/04/03/297853835/the-joys-and-ethics-of-insect-eating|accessdate=31 May 2014|date=3 April 2014}}</ref> Some entomophagy suppliers highlight the importance of humane insect treatment. For instance, World Ento uses the name "Good Karma Killing" to describe its process of freezing insects into a statis state.<ref name=WorldEnto2014>{{cite web|title=Current Products and Prices|url=http://worldento.wordpress.com/author/worldento/|publisher=World Ento|accessdate=31 May 2014|date=22 Oct 2013}}</ref> A 2013 [[FAO]] report on "Edible insects" includes a section encouraging high standards of welfare in entomophagy operations, despite uncertainty about whether insects can suffer.<ref name=FAO2013>{{cite book|author1=Arnold van Huis|author2=Joost Van Itterbeeck|author3=Harmke Klunder|author4=Esther Mertens|author5=Afton Halloran|author6=Giulia Muir|author7=Paul Vantomme|title=Edible insects: Future prospects for food and feed security|date=2013|publisher=Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations|location=Rome|isbn=978-92-5-107596-8|page=65|url=http://www.fao.org/docrep/018/i3253e/i3253e05.pdf|accessdate=1 June 2014|chapter=5.6. Animal Welfare}}</ref>
Others feel that considering the wellbeing of farmed insects is going too far. Rhys Southan suggests that even most [[veganism|vegans]] do not care a lot about insects, but that "Insects are to animal rights what [[Larry Flynt]] is to the First Amendment – you have to uphold their rights even if you don’t want to, or the whole thing falls apart." He goes on to propose satirical slogans that insect-rights activists might use against entomophagy.<ref name=Southan2010>{{cite web|last=Southan|first=Rhys|title=The Vegan Response to the Insect Eating Movement?|url=http://letthemeatmeat.com/post/453418717/the-vegan-response-to-the-insect-eating-movement|accessdate=31 May 2014|date=18 March 2010}}</ref> [[Wesley J. Smith]] rejects a proposal that "We have to begin to ponder the welfare of insects we consume," adding: "See how crazy things get once human exceptionalism is rejected?"<ref name=Smith2014>{{cite web|last=Smith|first=Wesley J.|title=Don’t Hurt the Insects!|url=http://www.nationalreview.com/human-exceptionalism/376702/dont-hurt-insects-wesley-j-smith|publisher=National Review Online|accessdate=31 May 2014|date=28 April 2014}}</ref> Smith cites a parody website, "The Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Insects."<ref name=SPCI2006>{{cite web|title=The Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Insects|url=http://insectrights.org/parody.html|accessdate=31 May 2014|year=2006}}</ref> The site features an article feigning concern for the insects eaten alive by contestants on ''[[Survivor (TV series)|Survivor]]''.<ref name=RealityTV2006>{{cite web|title=Latest - Reality TV causes untold suffering|url=http://insectrights.org/celebrity.html|accessdate=31 May 2014|year=2006}}</ref>
== Welfare considerations for rearing ==
Because there is little standardized protocol for insect rearing, most farmers learn the best production methods by trial and error. For instance, if they kill an insect colony by setting the temperature too high, they avoid doing that in the future. Most breeders keep their techniques secret in order to avoid having them copied by other farms.<ref name=ErensEtAl2012 />
Because there are so many types of insects, it is not feasible to devise a single protocol for their treatment. Case-by-case understanding is required.<ref name=ErensEtAl2012>{{cite web|last=Erens|first=Jesse|title=A bug’s life: Large-scale insect rearing in relation to animal welfare|url=http://venik.nl/site/wp-content/uploads/2013/06/Rapport-Large-scale-insect-rearing-in-relation-to-animal-welfare.pdf|publisher=Wageningen University|accessdate=13 May 2014|last2=Es van|first2=Sam|last3=Haverkort|first3=Fay|last4=Kapsomenou|first4=Eleni|last5=Luijben|first5=Andy|year=2012}}</ref>
=== Disease ===
When viruses infect an insect-rearing facility, they spread rapidly and kill most of the insects.<ref name=DeGoedeEtAl2013 />
Humans can spread diseases to farmed insects. Thus, sanitation is very important, and only farm staff should have access to the insects. For instance, the company Van de Ven had a pathogen outbreak that killed all of its ''[[Zophobas morio]]'' worms, and the breeders hypothesized that the disease may have been brought by human visitors.<ref name=ErensEtAl2012 />
Giving insects a heat gradient may sometimes help prevent disease<ref name=ErensEtAl2012 /> because behavioral [[Insect thermoregulation|thermoregulation]] can suppress pathogens.<ref name=OuedraogoEtAl2004>{{cite journal|last1=Ouedraogo|first1=R. M.|author2=M. S. Goettel|author3=J. Brodeur|title=Behavioral thermoregulation in the migratory locust: a therapy to overcome fungal infection|journal=Oecologia|date=2004|volume=138|issue=2|pages=312–319|doi=10.1007/s00442-003-1431-0}}</ref>
=== Humidity ===
Walter Jansen's Jagran company raises [[housefly]] larvae for use as animal feed. Humidity needs to be carefully controlled to avoid dehydrating or drowning the insects.<ref name=ErensEtAl2012 />
=== Temperature ===
Insects are [[poikilothermic]], but maintaining an adequate temperature range remains important.<ref name=DeGoedeEtAl2013 /> For example, mealworms thrive best when living close together, but this can lead to overheating if temperature is not controlled.<ref name=ErensEtAl2012 />
=== Cannibalism ===
Some insects like locusts begin eating each other when they become overcrowded or malnourished. Adequate space and nutrition are important to prevent this.<ref name=ErensEtAl2012 />
== Slaughter methods ==
===Developing world===
[[Entomophag]]y is common in many developing countries, such as [[Thai cuisine#Insects|Thailand]] and [[Chapulines|Mexico]]. Usually killing is done without [[euthanasia]]. For instance: [[Image:Chapulines.jpg|thumb|right|Chapulines at [[Tepoztlán]]'s market, near [[Mexico City]].]] * [[Termite]]s are either eaten alive directly where they're found or are brought home to be roasted over coals or fried. * [[Cicada]]s are boiled, fried, or sautéed. * [[True water bug|Water bug]]s may be eaten whole, steamed, fried, or roasted and canned. * [[Scorpion]]s are skewered alive and fried in oil. * [[Tarantula]]s are fried in oil or roasted over a fire.<ref name=Greenfield2011>{{cite web|last=Greenfield|first=Beth|title=15 Insects You Won't Believe Are Edible|url=http://www.budgettravel.com/feature/15-insects-you-wont-believe-are-edible,7925/|publisher=Budget Travel|accessdate=1 June 2014|date=21 Oct 2011}}</ref> In [[Silveiras]], Brazil, residents pluck the wings off ants and then either fry them or dip them in chocolate.<ref name=Weiner2011>{{cite web|last1=Weiner|first1=Miriam B.|title=Countries That Eat Bugs|url=http://travel.usnews.com/features/Countries_That_Eat_Bugs/|publisher=U.S. News & World Report|accessdate=1 June 2014|date=28 Apr 2011}}</ref> In Thailand, crickets are gathered fresh in the morning and then fried.<ref name=Thailand2013>{{cite web|author=Lara|title=Eating Insects in Thailand|url=http://www.travelinthailand.org/eating-insects-in-thailand/|website=Travel in Thailand|accessdate=1 June 2014|date=6 Mar 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140119175140/http://www.travelinthailand.org/eating-insects-in-thailand/|archivedate=19 Jan 2014}}</ref>
===Industrial farms===
Little research has been done on humane methods of killing insects for consumption.<ref name=DeGoedeEtAl2013 />
The most common killing methods used by entomophagy companies in the Netherlands are freezing and dry-freezing (i.e., freezing and reducing pressure in order to extract water from the insects).<ref name=DeGoedeEtAl2013 />
Protix Biosystems kills its [[Hermetia illucens|black soldier flies]] by shredding, since its end product is a powder. Death takes less than a second. Tarique Arsiwalla at Protix said shredding makes sense because Western consumers are more likely to accept powdered insects than whole insects.<ref name=ErensEtAl2012 />
The Jagran company has tried asphyxiation, cooling, freeze-drying, boiling, and shredding. Managing Director Walter Jansen believes that shredding is most humane.<ref name=ErensEtAl2012 />
The Kreca company kills its animal-feed insects by putting them into a fridge or freeze-drying them. Insects destined for human consumption are first sterilized in hot water and then are refrigerated or freeze-dried.<ref name=ErensEtAl2012 />
FAO's "Edible insects" report suggests: "Insect-killing methods that would reduce suffering include freezing or instantaneous techniques such as shredding."<ref name=FAO2013 />
====Freezing====
While freezing is sometimes said to be a humane way to kill certain arthropods,<ref name=King2014 /><ref name=Euthanizing2012>{{cite web|title=Euthanizing Insects|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6Wr6E44nBlU|publisher=Colorado Plateau Biodiversity Center|accessdate=31 May 2014|date=6 Aug 2012}}</ref> others dispute this.<ref name=Pizzi2012>{{cite book|last=Pizzi|first=Romain|title=Invertebrate Medicine|date=2012|publisher=Wiley-Blackwell|isbn=978-0813817583|page=211|edition=2nd|editor=Gregory A. Lewbart|chapter=Spiders}}</ref><ref name=GunkelLewbart2007>{{cite book|author1=Cornelia Gunkel|author2=Gregory A. Lewbart|editor1=Gary West|editor2=Darryl Heard|editor3=Nigel Caulkett|title=Zoo Animal & Wildlife Immobilization and Anesthesia|date=2007|publisher=Blackwell|isbn=978-0-8138-2566-3|pages=147–158|chapter=13. Invertebrates}}</ref> According to "[[American Veterinary Medical Association|AVMA]] Guidelines for the Euthanasia of Animals," freezing is "not considered to be humane" when not preceded by another form of anesthesia.<ref name=AVMA2013>{{cite web|title=AVMA Guidelines for the Euthanasia of Animals: 2013 Edition|url=https://www.avma.org/kb/policies/documents/euthanasia.pdf|page=76|publisher=American Veterinary Medical Association|accessdate=12 May 2014}}</ref> The [[British and Irish Association of Zoos and Aquariums]] (BIAZA) Terrestrial Invertebrate Working Group (TIWG) reports on a survey conducted by Mark Bushell of BIAZA institutions. He found that refrigeration and freezing were the most common methods "of euthanasia of invertebrates although research has suggested that this is probably one of the least ethical options." That said, freezing is a worst-case method if chemical or instantaneous physical destruction is not possible.<ref name=BIAZA2013>{{cite book|author1=Sarah Pellett|author2=Romain Pizzi|author3=Steven Trim|author4=Mark Bushell|author5=Dave Clarke|author6=Jamie Wood|title=BIAZA Recommendations for Ethical Euthanasia of Invertebrates|date=Apr 2013|publisher=British and Irish Association of Zoos and Aquariums|edition=1.1}}</ref>
===Hobbyist entomophagy===
Some "how to" guides for eating insects make no mention of freezing or other euthanasia methods. For example, Miles Olson recommends * suffocating or roasting ants * decapitating, gutting, and then stewing, roasting, or sautéing slugs * steaming and slicing snails * frying, roasting, toasting, suffocating, or drowning crickets * drowning, squeezing, and then stir frying or stewing earthworms * eating aphids raw and so on.<ref name=Olson2012>{{cite book|last1=Olson|first1=Miles|title=Unlearn, Rewild: Earth Skills, Ideas and Inspiration for the Future Primitive|date=2012|publisher=New Society Publishers|isbn=978-0865717213|pages=193–202|chapter=22. Exploring Entomophagy: Bugs as Food}}</ref>
The website Insects Are Food suggests refrigerating insects to slow them down without killing them, prior to boiling or otherwise cooking them.<ref name=IAF>{{cite web|title=IAF Frequently Asked Questions|url=http://www.insectsarefood.com/faq.html|website=Insects Are Food|accessdate=1 June 2014}}</ref>
Other guides recommend freezing first.<ref name=Price>{{cite web|last=Price|first=Aletheia|title=Eating Bugs!|url=http://www.manataka.org/page160.html|accessdate=31 May 2014}}</ref><ref name=Tarantola2013>{{cite web|last1=Tarantola|first1=Andrew|title=Why, How, and Where You Should Start Eating Bugs|url=https://gizmodo.com/why-how-and-where-you-should-start-eating-bugs-1301815024|website=Gizmodo|accessdate=1 June 2014|date=16 Sep 2013}}</ref> [[Timothy Ferriss]] recounts what he observed when roasted his insects without freezing them first: "Suffice it to say, merely sedated crickets make horrible noises if you roast them, and the visual is far, far worse. Do yourself a favor and freeze them."<ref name=Ferriss2012>{{cite book|last=Ferriss|first=Timothy|title=The 4-Hour Chef: The Simple Path to Cooking Like a Pro, Learning Anything, and Living the Good Life|date=2012|publisher=New Harvest|isbn=978-0547884592}}</ref>
===Live insect feed===
Sometimes insects are not killed by farming companies but are sold [[Live food|live]], for consumption by fish and pets. 95% of the Kreca company's insects are sold live. Of the 1500 kg per week of mealworms produced by the Van de Ven company, most are sold as live feed.<ref name=ErensEtAl2012 />
Many suppliers of insects for reptiles offer live bugs and worms.<ref name=Livefoods>{{cite web|title=Livefoods Direct Ltd - Britain's Foremost Supplier Of Livefoods|url=http://www.livefoodsdirect.co.uk/|accessdate=1 June 2014}}</ref><ref name=Reptilefood>{{cite web|title=Reptilefood.com|url=http://www.reptilefood.com/|accessdate=1 June 2014}}</ref><ref name=Timberline>{{cite web|title=Timberline Live Pet Food|url=http://www.timberlinefisheries.com/|accessdate=1 June 2014}}</ref> Monitor lizards are typically fed live insects and may not eat pre-killed ones.<ref name=Monitor>{{cite web|title=The Monitor FAQ--Feeding|url=http://www.kingsnake.com/monitorfaq/feeding.htm|accessdate=1 June 2014}}</ref> Amphibians typically require live insects—wild-caught, home-grown, or bought at a pet store—although some like [[axolotls]] can be fed chunks of meat.<ref name=NZFrogs>{{cite web|title=Keeping Frogs!|url=http://www.nzfrogs.org/Resources/Kids+Information/Keeping+Frogs.html|website=New Zealand Frogs|accessdate=1 June 2014}}</ref> It's generally hard to convert reptiles and amphibians that eat insects to pre-killed prey,<ref>{{cite web|last1=Kaplan|first1=Melissa|title=Feeding Prekilled vs. Live Prey|url=http://www.anapsid.org/prekill.html|website=Melissa Kaplan's Herp and Green Iguana Information Collection|accessdate=1 June 2014|date=1 Jan 2014}}</ref> though some pet owners can feed dead insects by moving or dangling them.<ref name=FrogForum>{{cite web|title=Pre-killed feeding?|url=http://www.frogforum.net/food-feeders-live-frozen-culturing-etc/3003-pre-killed-feeding.html|website=Frog Forum|accessdate=1 June 2014|date=3–5 June 2010}}</ref> Bearded dragons can be fed dead crickets by hiding them in other food, dangling them with tongs, squirting them with water, or vibrating a bowl.<ref name=Team>{{cite web|last1=Team|first1=Ben|title=How to Get Bearded Dragons to Eat Canned Crickets|url=http://animals.pawnation.com/bearded-dragons-eat-canned-crickets-5897.html|website=PawNation|accessdate=1 June 2014}}</ref>
Pet spiders, praying mantids, and other insectivorous bugs typically require live food.<ref name=KeepingInsects>{{cite web|author=Linda|title=Feeder insects for your predatory insects|url=http://www.keepinginsects.com/general-care/live-food/|website=Keeping Insects|accessdate=1 June 2014}}</ref> Hedgehogs can be fed live, freeze-dried, or canned insects.<ref name=Dick>{{cite web|last1=Dick|first1=Gail|title=Insects a La Carte|url=http://www.hedgehogheadquarters.com/secure/insects.htm|website=Hedgehog Headquarters|accessdate=1 June 2014}}</ref>
Live worms and insects are commonly used as [[fishing bait]], with the result that they are either eaten alive by fish or drowned.
== Farmed insects not used for protein ==
Many vegans [[Veganism#Milk.2C eggs.2C honey and silk|avoid honey and silk]] because these require insect farming, even though the insects are not eaten. Silk production [[Silk#Animal rights|involves]] boiling silk worms alive in their cocoons.
The red pigment carmine [[Carmine#Production|is produced]] from powdered bodies of [[scale insect]]s, so some vegans avoid it.<ref name=CarmineVegan>{{cite web|title=Is Carmine Vegan?|url=http://www.isitvegan.com/2011/03/10/is-carmine-vegan/|website=Is It Vegan?|accessdate=1 June 2014|date=10 Mar 2011}}</ref><ref name=Shreeves2012>{{cite web|last1=Shreeves|first1=Robin|title=What is carmine and why is Starbucks taking it out of its products?|url=http://www.mnn.com/food/healthy-eating/blogs/what-is-carmine-and-why-is-starbucks-taking-it-out-of-its-products|website=Mother Nature Network|accessdate=1 June 2014|date=24 Apr 2012}}</ref><ref name=Yacoubou2013>{{cite web|last1=Yacoubou|first1=Jeanne|title=Alternatives to Insect-Derived Food Colors|url=http://www.vrg.org/blog/2013/01/02/alternatives-to-insect-derived-food-colors/|website=Vegetarian Resource Group Blog|accessdate=1 June 2014|date=2 Jan 2013}}</ref>
[[Shellac]] is produced from a resin secreted by the [[Kerria lacca|lac bug]] on specific trees in Asia. In addition to its use in industry, shellac is incorporated into some fruits, coffee beans, and candies as [[confectioner's glaze]]. Some vegans avoid confectioner's glaze because lac bugs may be killed during shellac production.<ref name=Yacoubou2010>{{cite web|last1=Yacoubou|first1=Jeanne|title=Q & A on Shellac|url=http://www.vrg.org/blog/2010/11/30/q-a-on-shellac/|website=Vegetarian Resource Group|accessdate=3 July 2014|date=30 Nov 2010}}</ref><ref name=Flinn2011>{{cite web|last1=Flinn|first1=Angel|title=Shellac & Food Glaze|url=http://gentleworld.org/shellac-food-glaze/|website=Gentle World|accessdate=3 July 2014|date=15 Aug 2011}}</ref> [[Lac]] used to produce red dye may be even more injurious to lac bugs because while shellac comes from lac-bug secretions, lac dye's color comes from the insect bodies themselves.<ref name=FAO1995Ch5>{{cite book|last1=Green|first1=C. L.|title=Non-Wood Forest Products 4: Natural colourants and dyestuffs|date=1995|publisher=Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations|location=Rome|url=http://www.fao.org/docrep/v8879e/v8879e08.htm|accessdate=3 July 2014|chapter=5: Insect Dyes}}</ref>
==See also== {{portal|Insects|Agriculture and Agronomy|Food}} * [[Insect farming]] * [[Insect euthanasia]]

revision.text:
'''Wide span vehicle''' is a special type of farming vehicle that is much wider than a typical vehicle. '''Wide span vehicles''' can measure up to {{convert|10|m|ft|adj=on}} wide or wider. The impetus behind wide span vehicles in farming is to reduce the amount of soil that becomes damaged (''e.g.'', from compaction) from farm vehicles. [[Controlled traffic farming]] (CTF) is also aimed at solving this problem and both CTF and wide span vehicles can be used together to further improve land use.
The many benefits of using wide span vehicles in farming include improved soil quality, less land lost to wheelways, increase in farm profits, less fuel use, reduced chemical use from more precise application, and increased types of land available for [[organic farming]].<ref>{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Controlled Traffic Farming: Wide Span | work = | publisher = | date = | url = http://www.controlledtrafficfarming.com/content/widespan.aspx | format = | doi = | accessdate = 23 July 2012 }} </ref>
==History==
[[David Dowler]] was a pioneer of wide span vehicle farming and created a first prototype gantry, called P1, in January 1978.<ref>{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = David Dowler - a history | work = | publisher = | date = 19 August 2007 | url = http://www.controlledtrafficfarming.com/downloads/David%20Dowler%20-%20a%20history.pdf | format = | doi = | accessdate = 23 July 2012 }} </ref> Dowler went on to build and apply for patents on many wide span-related machines.
